onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 460601633, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_686889522" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/686889522" />    <a title="Brian Yahn" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22849115-brian-yahn"><img alt="Brian Yahn" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464719293p2/22849115.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/686889522?book_show_action=false">Jun 26, 2016</a>      <a title="Brian Yahn" class="user" name="Brian Yahn" href="/user/show/22849115-brian-yahn">Brian Yahn</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer686889522" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7567531454249957333">In the Harry Potter series, J.K. Rowling perfects the most important rule of story telling: be interesting. Her prose might not be great (although it is good), her plots and mysteries might be a little convoluted. But damn can she tell an interesting story, build a fun world, and put great characters in it.<br /><br />From the first sentence, she lets you know what fun you're in for. There's just that magical touch to it only she seems to have. And she keeps it going through the whole book (and the six othe</span>  <span id="freeText7567531454249957333" style="display:none">In the Harry Potter series, J.K. Rowling perfects the most important rule of story telling: be interesting. Her prose might not be great (although it is good), her plots and mysteries might be a little convoluted. But damn can she tell an interesting story, build a fun world, and put great characters in it.<br /><br />From the first sentence, she lets you know what fun you're in for. There's just that magical touch to it only she seems to have. And she keeps it going through the whole book (and the six others in the series) without missing a beat.<br /><br />The Sorcerer's Stone is packed with mystery. It starts early and picks up speed, burning through pages, right to the reveal, which is quite the surprise--no Scooby-Doo ending here.<br /><br />But the thing that really makes this book stand out is the characters. Harry Potter ended up getting on my last nerve in the series, but in this book, he's crazy likable. The minor characters are what really make the series, though. They have more personality than the protagonist of most books.<br /><br />This series might not be the best, but there's nothing like it. It's just magical. Plain and simple.</span>  <a data-text-id="7567531454249957333" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review686889522">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link686889522" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=686889522&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_686889522'><a id="like_count_review_686889522" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/686889522?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">115 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_686889522" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_686889522" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=115&rating[page]=1&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=686889522&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_686889522" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 686889522, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">2 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/686889522?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=1">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_686889522' style='display: none;'><div id="comment_153465141" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Philip" href="/user/show/30863291-philip"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1475274737p1/30863291.jpg" alt="30863291" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/30863291-philip">Philip</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer17818453807488752404">Great review! On paper this series could have ended up being an exercise in reinventing the wheel. What it lacks in ingenuity, though, it makes up for</span>  <span id="freeText17818453807488752404" style="display:none">Great review! On paper this series could have ended up being an exercise in reinventing the wheel. What it lacks in ingenuity, though, it makes up for in sheer entertainment value.</span>  <a data-text-id="17818453807488752404" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Jun 26, 2016 02:05PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_153471953" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Brian Yahn" href="/user/show/22849115-brian-yahn"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464719293p1/22849115.jpg" alt="22849115" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/22849115-brian-yahn">Brian Yahn</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer2264863039466046238">@Philip, couldn't agree more [=</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Jun 26, 2016 05:17PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_686889522' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 686889522, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_34349045" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/34349045" />    <a title="Nikki" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/223837-nikki"><img alt="Nikki" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1308224598p2/223837.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/34349045?book_show_action=false">Aug 17, 2011</a>      <a title="Nikki" class="user" name="Nikki" href="/user/show/223837-nikki">Nikki</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780747532743" href="/book/show/72193.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/223837-nikki?shelf=children-s-and-ya">children-s-and-ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/223837-nikki?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer34349045" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7243040787402949941">EDIT NOTE in 2012: Since this apparently isn't obvious, I wrote the review <i>years</i> ago. I do not necessarily have those opinions now. I wouldn't know; I haven't read Harry Potter since. With a degree and five more birthdays behind me I do not necessarily agree with everything I said when I was seventeen years old. I'm happy to chat about the definition of literature with you, or what I think about the Harry Potter phenomenon now or whatever, but try and be civil and don't attack me right out of th</span>  <span id="freeText7243040787402949941" style="display:none">EDIT NOTE in 2012: Since this apparently isn't obvious, I wrote the review <i>years</i> ago. I do not necessarily have those opinions now. I wouldn't know; I haven't read Harry Potter since. With a degree and five more birthdays behind me I do not necessarily agree with everything I said when I was seventeen years old. I'm happy to chat about the definition of literature with you, or what I think about the Harry Potter phenomenon now or whatever, but try and be civil and don't attack me right out of the gate.<br /><br />EDIT NOTE in 2011: I've edited this review to take out some teenage arrogance, but the rest is as-is. A few years later and with a degree in hand, including modules in Children's Lit, I could probably write a better review, but people seem to like this one!<br /><br /><br />I really don't like Harry Potter. It's one of those little concealed but apparently not widely known facts about me, which shocks everyone when I say I love books and they're all, "yeah, rite, Harry Potter is so awesum rite?" and I say "...no, it really isn't." I confess: when I was eleven or twelve or so, I read them. I also read the Sabrina the Teenage Witch novels. I read <i>everything</i> and wasn't very discriminating about it. I did enjoy them. I continued to enjoy them until I got to Order of the Phoenix, and then I decided that all the hype aside, I just wasn't interested anymore. Bear in mind, then, for the rest of this "essay", that I have only read up to and including The Goblet of Fire.<br /><br />Cue a few years of irritation while everyone insisted I <i>must</i> read the rest of the books, and how <i>dare</i> I prefer Tolkien and Ursula Le Guin (and later, Susan Cooper). I have really no objection to people reading the books and enjoying them, taking part in the fandom that surrounds them, dressing up in witchy costumes to go and pick up the most recently released volume at midnight. Have fun with that! As far as I'm concerned you're welcome to. I'm even quite happy to concede that yes, Harry Potter did get more people reading. Whether it got them reading literature or not is another matter: how many people, I wonder, have discovered a mania for reading after reading Harry Potter and then gone onto the likes of Crime and Punishment and War and Peace, or even Lord of the Rings? Not that many, I'll bet. I think they're probably reading Twilight and the like, more often than not. Not that it matters -- as long as people are reading.<br /><br />But in any case, I. Don't. Have. To. Read. Them. Just because I like books, does not mean I like <i>those</i> books. And I detest it every time someone shoves them in my face as 'great literature'. I actually had to study Harry Potter, for my English Lit/Lang A Level (for those unfamiliar with our system: A Levels are exams you take when you're about eighteen, which among other things determine whether you can go to university). One of the questions we had to figure out how to answer was whether we thought Harry Potter was good literature, whether we thought it would stand the test of time, and how it was suited to the time it's currently in.<br /><br />It was then that I figured out that, yeah, there are things wrong with Harry Potter beyond just the hype that was irritating me so much and the feeling that Rowling in no way matched up to the giants of fantasy and sci-fi, like Tolkien. I studied it alongside Tom Brown's Schooldays, by Thomas Hughes. Do note that I didn't like that book either. But it's a well written, well shaped, well considered book -- and it doesn't use the same cheap tricks as Harry Potter does. I'm not going to say much about that, since it's not a book I liked: if I'm going to compare/contrast, I'll compare with my favourite book that is also supposed to be for younger readers, Susan Cooper's <i>The Dark Is Rising</i>.<br /><br />There's nothing wrong with Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone being an amateur first novel. 'cause that's what it is. I'm sure many people's first novels don't even see the light of day, and yet Harry Potter somehow made it to a publisher's and was accepted. The thing is, people mostly refuse to recognise that and the cheap tricks J. K. Rowling uses. For example, her character's names. 'Draco Malfoy'. Mal, the French for bad, immediately obvious. 'Draco', suggesting dragon? Or perhaps 'draconian', which has negative connotations aplenty (not that I'd necessarily attribute those particular ones to Draco). Not very subtle, is it? 'Dumbledore'. Who <i>doesn't</i> get the image of a well-meaning, if strange, old man? 'Minerva', straight out of Greek myth: a goddess of knowledge. Gee, I wonder why Rowling chose that for a female teacher... 'Remus Lupin', 'Sirius Black', 'Mad-Eye Moody'... Do I even have to say anything?<br /><br />And 'Harry Potter'. Nothing striking about that: perfectly ordinary, as names go, right?<br /><br />Yeah. And that's the point. Harry Potter himself is not a real character -- certainly not at first. He's a cypher, a convenient space into which a kid can very easily insert himself or even herself. He's brave. Okay, generic hero characteristic. He has doubts. Again, the same. He has a Tragic Past. Don't we all? Or don't we all like to think we do? Look at the Mary Sues/self inserts people write in fandom -- so often they're people with incredibly dark, melodramatic pasts that they rise above. Harry Potter is a convenient place to insert yourself. The other characters are archetypes more than anything -- Hermione, the know it all girl; Ron, the loyal friend; Dumbledore, the mentor; Malfoy, the rival...<br /><br />All of that is actually what makes Harry Potter a highly readable, enjoyable book, for young people and even adults. It's targeted very precisely toward the readership of today. Maybe that makes J. K. Rowling a better author than I might paint her as, that she can know her audience so well -- there's that view, I'm sure. But it's all very basic, and I tend to look on it as cheap tricks. The whole chapter, in the first book, about the Mirror of Erised -- how sad does it make you feel for Harry? It's sentimental, it's sad -- and it's meant to do that, very obviously. There's a whole chapter written <i>just</i> to enforce the love between the members of Harry Potter's family.<br /><br />Susan Cooper does it in a single paragraph that makes me want to cry every single time I read it, coming after all the build up of guilt and pain in the relationship. "Bran went to [his father] and put his arm round his waist, and stood close. It was the first gesture of affection between the two that Will had ever seen. And wondering, loving surprise woke in Owen Davies's worn face as he looked down at the boy's white head, and the two stood there, waiting."<br /><br />That paragraph does for me what Rowling's whole chapter cannot. It's so effective, actually, because Cooper spends a whole book leading up to it, <i>showing</i> us Owen and Bran's relationship. Rowling shows us Harry's parents, but in an unsubtle way that actually throws me out of it because I think, "Oh, yeah, this is the chapter in which we're supposed to feel very sorry for Harry."<br /><br />There's also a very easy, blunt misdirection. You're supposed to hate Snape, supposed to believe he's the one to blame for everything, and at the end, you're supposed to be as surprised as Harry when it's Quirrel waiting there for him. At the age of eleven, I think I went right along with that, but when I reread it for A Level, I had to wince at how heavy-handed the misdirection was. I understand that later in the series Snape comes into it more, and I don't know whether the misdirection turns out to be not that misdirected when it comes down to the real truth: but in the first book, you're meant to believe it's Snape all along, and I don't think J. K. Rowling does a very good job of giving us clues that it's not actually Snape, because she's so busy blackening him to lead people astray.<br /><br />It's also very black-and-white. Questions aren't raised, by this story -- and that's a thing I think is actually important in literature. Raise questions, discuss issues, end with a question. I don't know what to call stories that don't fit into that, really. I'm going to go with 'novels' as opposed to literature. Harry Potter is a novel. It's a story. I don't think it has any real lasting values. Susan Cooper's books, while also quite basic, discussing the Light and the Dark, do end with a question. If man is left on earth, to do as man will, will man be Light or Dark? The immortals leave earth, and say that the world -- for better or worse -- belongs to humans. Right now, a lot of people think the answer to that question would be 'worse'. But Harry Potter does not raise this question, does not raise any question, and does not answer one either. That's why I don't think it will last except perhaps as a phenomenon to be studied: the 'Potter mania' and what caused it.<br /><br />That's why I don't like Rowling's writing. It's not particularly refined, it's unsubtle -- and that's okay, you know, I'm not saying you can't enjoy that, can't find it refreshing. I don't. I'm also not saying that 'novels' are bad -- they're good, they can provide valuable escapism, they can be incredibly rich fodder for the imagination, and I suspect Harry Potter is, for many children. But I don't call it literature, and I myself don't <i>like</i> it.<br /><br />Note: the three star rating is because honestly, when I first read it, I did love it.</span>  <a data-text-id="7243040787402949941" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review34349045">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link34349045" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=34349045&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_34349045'><a id="like_count_review_34349045" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/34349045?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">114 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_34349045" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_34349045" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=114&rating[page]=1&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=34349045&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_34349045" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 34349045, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">124 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/34349045?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=1">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_34349045' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/34349045/comments?reverse=true">View all 124 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_145996963" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Rajan" href="/user/show/11662595-rajan"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1456507872p1/11662595.jpg" alt="11662595" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/11662595-rajan">Rajan</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer9727579603815447913">v thoroughly</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Jan 14, 2016 10:08AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_147364621" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Tria" href="/user/show/5148226-tria"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1470698658p1/5148226.jpg" alt="5148226" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/5148226-tria">Tria</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer7111602887060417640">Hm. Only just read this in full, now that you're in your mid-20s, &amp; tbqh I can sort of see where you're coming from. Having said that, though, a</span>  <span id="freeText7111602887060417640" style="display:none">Hm. Only just read this in full, now that you're in your mid-20s, & tbqh I can sort of see where you're coming from. Having said that, though, a lot of what you hated about the early books as a teenager are the same things that eventually got me to like them. <br /><br />I didn't start the series til the release of <em>Prisoner of Azkaban</em>, because at the time I was very against reading anything that had that much hype surrounding it - to be frank I was pretty arrogant when it came to "popular literature" in my mid-teens; I'm glad to say I've long since grown out of <em>that</em>. I still think the series was over-hyped in the beginning, but I also feel that she wrote it to mature with the group of readers who very literally grew up alongside Harry, and in that sense it rather did. <br /><br />I was 11 when the first book was released (Harry's age in the book, though if going by strict chronology it was set a few years before 1997 so he would not have been exactly my age, but we won't get into that), and my first midnight book release was the event for <em>Goblet of Fire</em>, when I was 14. I've never regretted that. I lived in a very rural village at the time, and though I went into the nearest town for midnight, the next bus home wasn't until 7 o'clock. Fortunately, I was on study leave at the time (private school exam schedules), and I spent the rest of the night sitting at a bus stop, reading the new book. I finished it in 6 and a half hours that first time, nicely convenient timing. <br /><br />Anyway, to move on, I went to every midnight book release in the series after that, including the final one, the very night after I'd caught the red-eye from Toronto to Manchester via JFK (and had my witch's costume left in New York with all my luggage, thanks to the airline! I was furious - I'd gone in costume to all the others, & couldn't go to the last that way because of a stupid screw-up on the part of a very poor - now defunct - company). I was 21 when the book series ended. I really did grow up with it, and that sort of has an effect all of its own in that it adds a little more affection for the complete set than I might otherwise have had. <br /><br />I don't particularly <em>like</em> Harry as a character - I don't recall whether or not I've ever mentioned that to you? Nor Ron. I loved the series, as a teenager, more for its secondary characters than the leading trio, with the exception of Hermione. Even now I only read femmeslash or Hermione/Snape AU fanfiction in the fandom. <br /><br />Anyway, part of what else attracted me to it was the way that Rowling <em>did</em> choose to play with tropes and language the way she did, but the way you seemed to loathe when writing this. You and I might have picked up on a great many of the references, and you clearly thought (at least at the time) that they were obvious, but one has to have been precocious at the age to which the books are aimed even to pick them all up. Many of the origins aren't taught in school now, and weren't for my generation or yours, though we're not hugely far apart that way. Many 11-year-olds and teenagers would not know: they'd wonder, and perhaps look them up, and learn more. But what I'm trying to get at here is this: that you and I knew the extra detail to begin with doesn't really make Rowling obvious in her references to her chosen audience, Nikki.<br /><br />All that said, I also have to disagree that the series doesn't raise any questions about anything important. The nature of love and hatred, and what traits, abilities, choices and actions make us the people we are and those whom we later become... all those are very central to the series. They may not be especially subtle, but again, this is directed at a specific audience and a generation that was no longer used to such subtlety as a whole and many people who might well have easily missed such concepts, were they less apparent than they were. So I disagree - and on that one I admit that I can't really see how you come to the conclusion that there are no topics such as these raised in the series.<br /><br />As far as Snape is concerned, I think we'll have to agree to disagree - I wondered from Book 1 what his motivations were, and can't remember ever assuming he was so broadly painted that he could only be thoroughly evil. Granted, much of Snape's characterisation pays off in better ways later in the series, and hindsight only improves the lot, so depending on whether you ever did finish it I suppose your view may be affected by that. But - not to push - I do think that if you never have, it might be worth a try just to see whether it affects your view of the earlier material. It certainly did mine.<br /><br />It's a decent review, though. I'm not criticising you: YMMV. And you admit to the teenage arrogance that's unfortunately quite present in it, so that gives you brownie points. o/</span>  <a data-text-id="7111602887060417640" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Feb 09, 2016 09:51PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_34349045' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 34349045, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div></div><div class="uitext" style="float: right; itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/6162618" />    <a title="Books Ring Mah Bell" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/372363-books-ring-mah-bell"><img alt="Books Ring Mah Bell" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1363111417p2/372363.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/6162618?book_show_action=false">Mar 19, 2009</a>      <a title="Books Ring Mah Bell" class="user" name="Books Ring Mah Bell" href="/user/show/372363-books-ring-mah-bell">Books Ring Mah Bell</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/372363-books-ring-mah-bell?shelf=kidsbooks">kidsbooks</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer6162618" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer18334999240838660107">I read this long long ago to see how "evil" it was. You know, does it encourage children to become witches and wizards? Does reading Harry Potter cause evil?<br /><br /><br />After chopping off the heads of chickens, bats, a stray cat, and mixing it up in a <s>cauldron</s> pot, I dipped in my voo-doo doll and put a curse on my neighbor. (nothing <i>too</i> bad, just a case of incurable body lice) I then decided <b>there is absoultely nothing wrong with Harry Potter!</b><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />*disclaimer for those who don't get my sarcasm: I never cut heads</span>  <span id="freeText18334999240838660107" style="display:none">I read this long long ago to see how "evil" it was. You know, does it encourage children to become witches and wizards? Does reading Harry Potter cause evil?<br /><br /><br />After chopping off the heads of chickens, bats, a stray cat, and mixing it up in a <s>cauldron</s> pot, I dipped in my voo-doo doll and put a curse on my neighbor. (nothing <i>too</i> bad, just a case of incurable body lice) I then decided <b>there is absoultely nothing wrong with Harry Potter!</b><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />*disclaimer for those who don't get my sarcasm: I never cut heads off any animal, ever. I open the door to let spiders and flies out of the house. So relax. (and let your kid read the damn book!)<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="18334999240838660107" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div id="reviewTextContainer1613651563" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8971017176529889685"><s>REVIEW TO COME ON SATURDAY</s><br><br><b>4.9 stars</b><br><br>this is the hardest review I have ever written because what can I say about Harry Potter?! But I'll try my best on writing this review ;) <br><br>Harry Potter is an eleven year old boy. He lives with aunt Petunia, uncle Vernon and his naughty cousin, Dudley. Harry's parents were dead when he was a toddler. They were killed. his uncle and aunt and cousin always treat him so badly. Harry even sleeps in a cupboard. But there's something special about him that he doesn't e</span>  <span id="freeText8971017176529889685" style="display:none"><s>REVIEW TO COME ON SATURDAY</s><br><br><b>4.9 stars</b><br><br>this is the hardest review I have ever written because what can I say about Harry Potter?! But I'll try my best on writing this review ;) <br><br>Harry Potter is an eleven year old boy. He lives with aunt Petunia, uncle Vernon and his naughty cousin, Dudley. Harry's parents were dead when he was a toddler. They were killed. his uncle and aunt and cousin always treat him so badly. Harry even sleeps in a cupboard. But there's something special about him that he doesn't even know it. Until a letter from Hogwarts arrives at his house and a big man named Hagrid tells him that he is a wizard...<br><br><b>  <u>My Opinion</u></b><br><br>don't freak out okay? because <b>this is the first time I read Harry Potter.</b> I know, I know. I'm so late but I think there's no such thing as too late when it comes to books. ;D<br><br>I read this because everyone that I know always loved this series. My big sister loved this series. My big brother also loved this series ( but he only have watched the movies, because he's not a reader ) and I think all my Goodreads friends also loved this series. So I was like " what am I waiting for?! I need to order this book" but the problem is I just bought the first book because I just wanted to try it and I had never thought that I would love this book so much. now I have to wait the next books to arrive at my home. I WAS SO STUPID!! <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1471710951ra/20096398.gif" width="250" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm serious, I even cried when I finished this book because :<br>1. <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[You know that ending, when Gryffindor wins the house cup. I was about to scream " GRYFFINDOR. GRYFFINDOR. GRYFFINDOR.!!" but I realised that me, my mom and my brother were in the same room and if I did that, I'm sure they would think I was crazy. xD.<br> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br>2. I DON'T HAVE THE SEQUEL!! <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1441724944ra/16144174.gif" width="250" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>guys, if you haven't read this book, I suggest you all to read it and don't just buy the first book. unless you want to end up like me.<br><br><b>  <u>Why Did I Give This Book 4.9 Stars?</u></b><br><br>I loved all the characters in this book, Except you, Malfoy. He always mocked Ron and it made me so angry! I mean, how could anyone hate Ron Weasley?! and guys I loved all the weasleys! George and Fred made me laugh so much and Percy! this cute boy who always said "Prefect" everytime. I wish I had friends like these guys. <br>oh! and the friendship between Harry, Ron and Hermione was so great! I always thought I was Hermione while reading it hahaha. <br><br>oh! and Peeves the poltergeist! I liked him so much! he always made me laugh! everytime he caused trouble I always laughed, he is my favorite ghost in this series and I hope I'll see him again in the sequel. guys, did you like him or hate him? and if Peeves isn't your favorite ghost, so who's your favorite ghost? tell me on comment section below!<br>so basically, I loved everything about this book. <br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1432320966ra/14933427.gif" width="280" height="200" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>To be honest, I have watched all the movies before reading the book. I guess I watched them all like... 5 years ago. I wasn't a reader that time. But thankfully I don't really remember about the story but I still do remember the ending. I wish I could forget it. T^T <br><br>I tried the test on pottermore a few days ago and the result was GRYFFINDOR. I <s> was </s> am so happy! what about you guys? <br><br>thank you guys for reading and liking this review! I hope you guys have an amazing weekend. Happy Reading!! </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_900860104" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/900860104" />    <a title="Delee" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6168268-delee"><img alt="Delee" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1431034088p2/6168268.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/900860104?book_show_action=false">Jun 02, 2014</a>      <a title="Delee" class="user" name="Delee" href="/user/show/6168268-delee">Delee</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780747532743" href="/book/show/72193.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>          <div>    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Delee by: </span>      <a href="/user/show/7091879-stepheny">Stepheny</a>  </div>          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=ya">ya</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=first-in-a-series">first-in-a-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=buddy-read">buddy-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6168268-delee?shelf=stepheny-made-me">stepheny-made-me</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer900860104" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11775193208187933808">I wish this book had come out when I was young, I wish that someone had convinced me to read them when they first came out, and I wish I had read this series before I watched the movies...I wish..I wish..I wish...<br><br>I wish I wasn't a Muggle.<br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401730393i/9839381.png" alt=" photo 3b294801-b8c6-44cc-8a99-38fde1ebba12_zpsfc159743.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The day started off the same as any other day for Vernon Dursley- he picked out his clothes for work, got dressed, listened to his wife- Petunia- as she struggled with their son -Dudley- during one of his tantrums, grabbed his briefcase, kissed them both good-by</span>  <span id="freeText11775193208187933808" style="display:none">I wish this book had come out when I was young, I wish that someone had convinced me to read them when they first came out, and I wish I had read this series before I watched the movies...I wish..I wish..I wish...<br><br>I wish I wasn't a Muggle.<br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401730393i/9839381.png" alt=" photo 3b294801-b8c6-44cc-8a99-38fde1ebba12_zpsfc159743.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The day started off the same as any other day for Vernon Dursley- he picked out his clothes for work, got dressed, listened to his wife- Petunia- as she struggled with their son -Dudley- during one of his tantrums, grabbed his briefcase, kissed them both good-bye, got into his car and drove away from number four Privet drive. That is where the day took a strange turn...Vernon just chose to ignore it.<br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401730530i/9839401.jpg" alt=" photo b701484b-7f77-4302-a1d4-7485c76dcfb0_zps749528ed.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401730530i/9839402.jpg" alt=" photo c055ad88-d5dd-437e-9181-f114d31462dd_zpsacf0d36d.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>He ignored the cat reading a map on the street corner outside his home. He ignored the people dressed in cloaks...He ignored the owls flying outside his window at work- and after some careful consideration, he decided to also ignore the whispers on the streets outside at lunch- mentioning the name Harry Potter, and the strange man that hugged him for no reason...If Vernon had been a different sort of man- he would have known life was about to change for his "happy' little family.<br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401730393i/9839383.jpg" alt=" photo 48c0fdd9-89da-49af-a15a-90e6f423e263_zps87100f9b.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401737307i/9840538.jpg" alt=" photo ee275d3b-5a46-4050-83b5-ef3fc7c3bce0_zpsde593d9b.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The street lights on Privet drive flicker off one by one- and a group of four gather just outside the Dursley residence. Dumbledore, Professor McGonagall and Hargrid, set baby Harry and a letter on the doorstep. For Harry Potter isn't just any child and must be kept safe. One day he will know who he is, and one day they will come back for him.<br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401737179i/9840525.jpg" alt=" photo 6bab0c1d-febe-4099-81c8-b2a716c9b85a_zps4b23e84f.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><img class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1401737179i/9840526.jpg" alt=" photo 2c231769-e503-4d5d-a111-2862819612c5_zps48bf9912.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>First off I would like to thank my friend Stepheny- for finally being the one to give me that extra push I needed to give in and read this wonderful book- and I do mean PUSH. She was relentless, and now I know why! Anything I say will pale in comparison to her review of HARRY POTTER AND THE PHILOSOPHER'S STONE- so I am going to link her review and let her words take over from here...<br><br><a target="_blank" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/241902710">https://www.goodreads.com/review/show...</a><br><br>Thanks Stepheny! :D<br><br><br><br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="11775193208187933808" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id='like_container_review_900860104'><a id="like_count_review_900860104" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/900860104?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">92 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 id='comments_for_review_900860104' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1405696135" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1405696135" />    <a title="Mikee Andrea (ReadWithMikee)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee"><img alt="Mikee Andrea (ReadWithMikee)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1475805558p2/44137919.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1405696135?book_show_action=false">Jan 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Mikee Andrea (ReadWithMikee)" class="user" name="Mikee Andrea (ReadWithMikee)" href="/user/show/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee">Mikee Andrea (ReadWithMikee)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Kindle Edition " href="/book/show/13562891-harry-potter-and-the-sorcerer-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=favorite-series">favorite-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/44137919-mikee-andrea-readwithmikee?shelf=ebooks">ebooks</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1405696135" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8522621634788838879"><blockquote> <b> <i>"He couldn't know that at this very moment, people meeting in secret all over the country were holding up their glasses and saying in hushed voices: 'To Harry Potter U+2014the boy who lived!'"</i> </b> </blockquote><br />What can I really say about the Harry Potter series that hasn't already been said before?<br /><br />When I was younger, I've always wanted to read the Harry Potter books. But as a child, I was <b>intimidated</b> by how thick the books were, including the first installment which also happens to be one of the more shorter books</span>  <span id="freeText8522621634788838879" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <b>    <i>"He couldn't know that at this very moment, people meeting in secret all over the country were holding up their glasses and saying in hushed voices: 'To Harry Potter U+2014the boy who lived!'"</i>  </b></blockquote><br />What can I really say about the Harry Potter series that hasn't already been said before?<br /><br />When I was younger, I've always wanted to read the Harry Potter books. But as a child, I was <b>intimidated</b> by how thick the books were, including the first installment which also happens to be one of the more shorter books in the series! It's a funny thought now considering how I read books even more than double the size of Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone. But last year, I made a resolution to read all the Harry Potter books starting in January and finishing no later than April because Universal Studios is finally opening <b>  <i>The Wizarding World of Harry Potter</i></b> theme park in California. And what better way to reward myself for finishing the series than taking a journey through the magical world of Harry Potter! <b>Chocolate Frogs, Bertie Bott's, Butter Beer, Hogwarts HERE I COME!</b><br /><br />With that being said, I really enjoyed this book as much as I thought I would. I loved seeing all the <b>  <i>"bonus scenes"</i></b> and dialogue that were excluded from the film and how different everything seemed as opposed to watching the films. However, I think I did enjoy the movie a bit more than the book. Maybe it's because I grew up watching the Harry Potter movies (and still do several times every year), rather than growing up and reading the books. So if anything, it's actually kind of backwards for me.<br /><br />I've noticed that the movie took on a more <b>  <u>darker</u></b> atmosphere compared to the lighter, more kid-friendly mood that the book possessed. A good example of this for me would be the Sorting Hat scene. In the movie, the Hat actually frightened and freaked me out and to be honest, it still does! But in the book, everyone's all happy and singing, and just <b>WAY</b> different from how I would've pictured it if I would have read the book first, then watched the movie. :P<br /><br />I'm really glad that the movie did such a fantastic job at depicting this book and, in some ways, <b>  <i>made it even better.</i></b> I thought I already knew the Wizarding World like the back of my hand but after reading Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone, it opened my eyes to a whole new perception that the movies could never have given me. Although being a fan isn't determined by whether or not you've read all the books or watched all the movies, I'm really proud of myself for finally tackling this once childhood fear of mine to read the Harry Potter series. And for me, it feels as if I'm kicking it up a notch as a Harry Potter fanatic who's seen the movies, and is finally one step closer to finishing the books. :)</span>  <a data-text-id="8522621634788838879" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1405696135" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1405696135" ref="like" comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1405696135?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1405696135' style='display: </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_5634737" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/5634737" />    <a title="Mike" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/326814-mike"><img alt="Mike" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1242068159p2/326814.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/5634737?book_show_action=false">Sep 04, 2007</a>      <a title="Mike" class="user" name="Mike" href="/user/show/326814-mike">Mike</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was ok</span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="it was ok" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer5634737" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13438573968752359352">I'm not going to comment on the literary shortcomings of this book, the cliches, the painfully long narrative, the fact that the characters will not think about an issue for months, but then suddenly it becomes important again. Smarter people than me have already said all this.<br /><br />What bothers me about the Harry Potter universe is its characterization of magic. Why is magic so easy in the Harry Potter universe? It's only moderately a matter of skill to use magic. Magic is mostly saying the correct w</span>  <span id="freeText13438573968752359352" style="display:none">I'm not going to comment on the literary shortcomings of this book, the cliches, the painfully long narrative, the fact that the characters will not think about an issue for months, but then suddenly it becomes important again. Smarter people than me have already said all this.<br /><br />What bothers me about the Harry Potter universe is its characterization of magic. Why is magic so easy in the Harry Potter universe? It's only moderately a matter of skill to use magic. Magic is mostly saying the correct word with the correct intonation and the correct flourish of the wand and boom! you've done something magical. If it were only for small things I don't think this would bother me so much, but the same works for more serious things, like killing someone.<br /><br />There is so much that is contrary to logic (and I don't mean science, I mean how reasonable people would behave) in the magic of Harry Potter that it drives me crazy. Why is the magical world so separated from the real world? What is their interaction? If magic works in the muggle world, what is preventing someone like Voldemort from completely taking over the muggle world? What is preventing any character from killing any other character by simpling saying the killing curse at any time? Human decency? Obviously there are a lot of characters in the books that don't have any. This never made any sense to me.<br /><br />I would like to draw a comparison with (and I'm sure people on a site about reading books will crucify me for mentioning TV, which is <i>obviously</i> incapable of being an art form) Buffy the Vampire Slayer. In Buffy, every time you use magic, you pay for it. For little things, like floating a pencil, you pay for it in concentration, and maybe a little physical energy, but not more than going for a walk. However, the more you take, the more you have to give back in one form or another. The show is not always entirely consistent on this, but the idea makes sense. To bring someone back from the dead, you have to kill something else, or pay some other kind of price. If you want to kill someone, there is a physical price, a mental price. Nothing is free. In Harry Potter, it seems like everything is free.<br /><br />It's always put me off, and every time a fan tries to explain to me why I'm wrong it sounds like a deus ex machina, or just a plain old stretch.<br /><br />Also, quidditch is the most pointless sport ever created. Only in 1 game out of 1000 does anything 99% of the action matter to the outcome of the game. Only the seeker and the bludgers mean anything.</span>  <a data-text-id="13438573968752359352" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review5634737">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link5634737" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=5634737&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_5634737'><a id="like_count_review_5634737" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/5634737?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">90 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_5634737" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_5634737" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=90&rating[page]=2&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=5634737&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_5634737" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 5634737, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">129 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/5634737?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=2">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_5634737' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/5634737/comments?reverse=true">View all 129 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_147819700" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Milla" href="/user/show/50541607-milla"><img src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assetsophoto/user/u_25x33-ccd24e68f4773d33a41ce08c3a34892e.png" alt="U 25x33" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/50541607-milla">Milla</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer765118395638542267">Have you read the fanfiction Harry Potter and the methods of Rationality?</span>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Feb 19, 2016 01:31PM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_149779102" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Jcb" href="/user/show/37450063-jcb"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1417326335p1/37450063.jpg" alt="37450063" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/37450063-jcb">Jcb</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer9411053000266502039">I appreciate that you're pointing out some of the absurdity of Harry Potter's magic world. I chalk it up to "suspension of disbelief." But, how do all</span>  <span id="freeText9411053000266502039" style="display:none">I appreciate that you're pointing out some of the absurdity of Harry Potter's magic world. I chalk it up to "suspension of disbelief." But, how do all these magical kids suddenly disappear from their school systems at age 11 without anyone seeming to noticwe or mind? The Weasley family has like four kids in Hogwarts; don't their teachers or neighbors wonder where the kids go off to school? Wouldn't Harry's uncle or cousin blow the whistle out of spite?</span>  <a data-text-id="9411053000266502039" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_884758975" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/884758975" />    <a title="P " class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25327841-p"><img alt="P " src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1469415764p2/25327841.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/884758975?book_show_action=false">Jul 19, 2016</a>      <a title="P " class="user" name="P " href="/user/show/25327841-p">P </a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780545582889" href="/book/show/17372039-harry-potter-and-the-sorcerer-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=favorites-2015">favorites-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25327841-p?shelf=re-read">re-read</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer884758975" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4528667570532235304"><blockquote> <b>Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much. They were the last people youU+2019d expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious, because they just didnU+2019t hold with such nonsense.</b> </blockquote><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456375447i/18225424._SY540_.jpg" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Re-read -</b> Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the first book of my life. I can remember when I was six and walked by a bookstore. Firstly, I didn't see it and then I rechecked the store again, that made me see this book sat on the</span>  <span id="freeText4528667570532235304" style="display:none"><blockquote>  <b>Mr. and Mrs. Dursley, of number four, Privet Drive, were proud to say that they were perfectly normal, thank you very much. They were the last people youU+2019d expect to be involved in anything strange or mysterious, because they just didnU+2019t hold with such nonsense.</b></blockquote><br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456375447i/18225424._SY540_.jpg" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>Re-read -</b> Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the first book of my life. I can remember when I was six and walked by a bookstore. Firstly, I didn't see it and then I rechecked the store again, that made me see this book sat on the self in the center of this store. I hadn't known anything about Harry Potter since then, all I know was it had a beautiful cover. So why didn't I give a try ?<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1456373803ra/18225329.gif" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>The first paragraph of this book is like magic. How can't you fall in love with the book narrated like a bedtime story and there's magic in it ? Frankly, I fall HARD for this book. It's my first love and the only one I can't forget. Harry Potter is a boy who lives in the cupboard under the stairs and his life isn't good either. He doesn't know that the letter arrived at his house will change his life forever. The story gradually reveals the secrets under and the world building is solid and intriguing. The magic systen is not complex but it enhances the story very good.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1435864667ra/15382854.gif" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><blockquote>  <b>U+201CTo the well-organized mind, death is but the next great adventure.U+201D</b></blockquote><br><br>Hogwart is a school that witches and wizards attend to. Harry feels like this is his second home since he first meets Ron and Hermione, his fellows. The journey starts the moment these three find out about the Sorcerer's stone and they think Snape is going to steal it for himself.<br><br>I won't say much about the story part because I'm sure eveyone knows it. All I want to say is about the emotional part, I loved how grievous when Harry looks into The Mirror of Erised and he sees his parents. I like the sentence Dumbledore tells him ...<br><br><blockquote>  <b>U+201CIt does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.U+201D</b></blockquote><br><br>When I was a child, I thought this book was really fun. But when I grow up, this book isn't just a book for me anymore. Harry Potter is an abused boy in his house and he has tolerated all along, no matter what. Harry Potter has a scar, that stands for everyone, we all have our scars and it's up to us to let it restrain your life or let it go and prove ourself not to be the person they think you are. Becoming more and being something bigger than the one those people think you can be.<br><br><blockquote>U+201CIt takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends.U+201D </blockquote><br><br>This book is EVERYTHING. My life. My passion. RECOMMEND TO EVERYONE !<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1456375447i/18225425._SX540_.jpg" width="400" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>More at <a target="_blank" href="http://goo.gl/dl6qbs" rel="nofollow">http://goo.gl/dl6qbs</a></span>  <a data-text-id="4528667570532235304" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1667572127" />    <a title="Rohisa" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6513101-rohisa"><img alt="Rohisa" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1466968986p2/6513101.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1667572127?book_show_action=false">Jul 21, 2016</a>      <a title="Rohisa" class="user" name="Rohisa" href="/user/show/6513101-rohisa">Rohisa</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=emo-heart-bible">emo-heart-bible</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=feverishly-compulsive">feverishly-compulsive</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=happiness-is-a-book">happiness-is-a-book</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=yay-to-nerds">yay-to-nerds</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=fanstyoozing-magic-licious">fanstyoozing-magic-licious</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=fantasymagic">fantasymagic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=growingup-is-a-bitch">growingup-is-a-bitch</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6513101-rohisa?shelf=dizzying-and-dazzling">dizzying-and-dazzling</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1667572127" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11688812911002195837">Harry Potter of House Gyrffindor, the first of his name, the Wizard born, <br />Father of Adventure Seeking, Protector of Hogwarts, The Khal of Magical Realm, Breaker of Dark Magic, The Unkilled.<br /><br />I finally read Harry Potter.<br /><br />Yes, you read that correctly. Somehow I made it through middle school, high school, and college without reading about the <i>Boy Who Lived</i>. <br /><br />Sometimes I feel twinges of regret about waiting so long to join in the magic. I wonder what my childhood would have been like, if IU+2019d been able t</span>  <span id="freeText11688812911002195837" style="display:none">Harry Potter of House Gyrffindor, the first of his name, the Wizard born, <br />Father of Adventure Seeking, Protector of Hogwarts, The Khal of Magical Realm, Breaker of Dark Magic, The Unkilled.<br /><br />I finally read Harry Potter.<br /><br />Yes, you read that correctly. Somehow I made it through middle school, high school, and college without reading about the <i>Boy Who Lived</i>. <br /><br />Sometimes I feel twinges of regret about waiting so long to join in the magic. I wonder what my childhood would have been like, if IU+2019d been able to grow up alongside Harry, Hermoine, and Ron. I look back at pictures of ecstatic, costumed children at book releases and movie premieres and think, <i>  <b>man, that could have been me!</b></i> I imagine how excruciating it would have been to wait years between the installments, instead of just a few days. (I know, IU+2019m incredibly spoiled).<br /><br />But at the same time, I know I was able to glean a whole lot from my first-time reading of Harry Potter that my 12-year old or 15-year old self would never have noticed or appreciated. ItU+2019s a testament to the vivid imagination, dedication, and literary prowess of J.K Rowling that for most of the series I barely felt at all that I was reading books meant for children.<br /><br />Here are just a few great things I took away from Harry Potter as a first-time, grown up reader.<br /><br /><b>The Sadness inside Harry</b>.<br /><br />Harry is our man. We get to see the world through his eyes. And, having lacked any kind of familial love and security as a child, naturally heU+2019s going to be a bit on the wild side. When youU+2019re a kid, youU+2019re happy to get into trouble right along with him! After all, youU+2019re learning about Hogwarts and the Wizarding world just like he is. But manU+2026as an adult, you really feel and understand the hurt, the loneliness Harry has to go through.<br /><br />HeU+2019s a kid who had so much working against him, and most of the people he trusted were either dead or lying to him for most of his life. As Harry matures and we see how much heU+2019s willing to sacrifice for those he loves, even the grown-ups canU+2019t help but take a page from HarryU+2019s book. HeU+2019s the boy who lived, loved, and won our hearts.<br /><br /><b>Hermoine is so incredibly inspiring</b><br /><br />OK, so, this is pretty obvious to anyone who reads the book, no matter their age. But itU+2019s even more powerful and inspiring to watch Hermoine grow up from an older perspective. She is the definition of a self-made woman. Hailing from muggle origins (the daughter of dentists, no less) only-child Hermoine Granger has to rely on her own gumption to succeed at Hogwarts. She doesnU+2019t have magical blood, a famous pedigree, a secret vault full of money, or even an older sibling to teach her the ropes. But gosh darn it, sheU+2019s got the library, and a copy of Hogwarts: A History, and sheU+2019s going to succeed if it kills her.<br /><br />As a fellow young woman trying to make my way in the world, how could Hermoine not be my hero? Her flaws teach me that humility is important to making my relationships work. Her strengths teach me that being a nerd is OK. Her care and preparedness save the day (and usually someoneU+2019s life).<br /><br /><b>Words Matter SO MUCH</b><br /><br />We all know this great quote from Dumbledore:<br /><br /><i>  <b>U+201CCall him Voldemort, Harry. Always use the proper name for things. Fear of a name increases fear of the thing itself.U+201D</b></i><br /><br />The older I grow, the more I realize how much pain in our world stems from fear and avoidance. And, as Dumbledore counseled, this only makes bad situations worse. When we see something rotten in the world and want to find a solution, we canU+2019t just chalk it up to some vague term. We have to call things what they are, whether itU+2019s U+201CRacism,U+201D U+201CSexism,U+201D or another of the many harmful ways humans treat each other. Just like Wizards couldnU+2019t unite to stand against vague U+201Cevil,U+201D something which could not be named, so we in the Muggle world have to be brave and name our Voldemorts when they arise, in order to effectively make a change<br /><br />My list could go on and on. But why not crack open The SorcererU+2019s Stone and revisit the magic for yourself? If itU+2019s been a while since you read the Potter books, youU+2019re in for an avalanche of new lessons and feels that you might have been too young to appreciate the first time around.<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="11688812911002195837" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1726107736" />    <a title="Luke Taylor" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/30710594-luke-taylor"><img alt="Luke Taylor" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1476826671p2/30710594.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1726107736?book_show_action=false">Aug 18, 2016</a>      <a title="Luke Taylor" class="user" name="Luke Taylor" href="/user/show/30710594-luke-taylor">Luke Taylor</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408855652" href="/book/show/22841994-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=hall-of-fame">hall-of-fame</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=i-own-a-copy">i-own-a-copy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=recommended-to-me">recommended-to-me</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/30710594-luke-taylor?shelf=magic">magic</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1726107736" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer2088870970309295624">So what is Harry Potter and The PhilosopherU+2019s Stone?<br /><br />Good question. But first I ask you, what <i>is</i> magic?<br /><br />To me, magic is the captivating voice of the imagination, transmutable and quantifiable, it finds its verve in the proper arrangement of words. These words can make you laugh, and cry, and dream dreams that will never die.<br /><br />It would go without saying that Jo Rowling changed the world when she created Harry Potter, and the result is a deeply meaningful and shareable universe as vast and grand as St</span>  <span id="freeText2088870970309295624" style="display:none">So what is Harry Potter and The PhilosopherU+2019s Stone?<br /><br />Good question. But first I ask you, what <i>is</i> magic?<br /><br />To me, magic is the captivating voice of the imagination, transmutable and quantifiable, it finds its verve in the proper arrangement of words. These words can make you laugh, and cry, and dream dreams that will never die.<br /><br />It would go without saying that Jo Rowling changed the world when she created Harry Potter, and the result is a deeply meaningful and shareable universe as vast and grand as Star Wars, Final Fantasy, and enrapturing works that have continued to span generations with the perfect combination of action, creativity, and character. As this is my very first reading of Harry Potter and I have never seen the movies (though some things have been spoiled, but not many) I was so happy to treat myself with the release of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/28796063.Vault_of_Dreams" title="Vault of Dreams by Luke Taylor">Vault of Dreams</a> to the UK Bloomsbury 2010 set that comes in a wonderful red box, and I have two lovely friends to thank for this, Chelsea (Slytherpuff) and Chenda (Slytherin), because without their friendship and enthusiasm, this vast landscape of literary gold would still be void in my life.<br /><br />Whilst Potter is undeniably English, its likability constitutes some of the very best qualities of Anglophilia (like Christmas pudding and the Hogwarts Express), and reminds us that the stone set in the silver sea has not only some of the greatest writers (male and female) the world has ever seen, but continues to capture our lust for fantastical adventure as a place so heavily steeped in magic, mystery, and muggle-dom, that PotterU+2019s inherent Englishness makes it overly charming and utterly adorable, and, for me, tearfully nostalgic. <br /><br />The very definition of timeless, not only for its colorful cast of characters (a true ensemble series this is! With someone for everyone to love or hate!) or its prose (lighter than C.S. LewisU+2019 Narnia but just as enchanting) or its cleverness and conceptualization, Harry Potter finds the precious space in our hearts that weU+2019ve all been endowed, the perfect space to live and dream and desire to be great, to know that destiny is a powerful force at work in our lives, but life is still and adventure full of choices, and the key to truly living is truly the most unexplainably magical idea there is, was, and ever will be, and that is love.<br /><br />Recommended for everyone!<br /><br />And get that beautiful red box set whilst you're at it! The covers are <3<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="2088870970309295624" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter
