maravillo y volver siempre es bueno.<br /><br />Me encanto tanto como la primera vez que lo leU+00ED, volver a leer Harry Potter siempre es un gran placer, sin duda una gran historia que siempre me va        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408845646" href="/book/show/24548235-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33269229-paul-nash?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33269229-paul-nash?shelf=childrens-and-young-adult">childrens-and-young-adult</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1491361474" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6734005276447247705">Absolutely fabulous!! I'm happy that I got to read an illustrated, non-altered version of Harry Potter year 1. It sucks they are only putting out one illustrated version per year. So it will be this fall until we see the Chamber of Secrets. :(<br /><br />UPDATED: I've already read this, but just finished it a 2nd time reading it to my children; doing all the voices and everything! (Note: I finished the ILLUSTRATED VERSION for the 2nd time. I've read book 1 & the rest of the series too many times). THEY</span>  <span id="freeText6734005276447247705" style="display:none">Absolutely fabulous!! I'm happy that I got to read an illustrated, non-altered version of Harry Potter year 1. It sucks they are only putting out one illustrated version per year. So it will be this fall until we see the Chamber of Secrets. :(<br /><br />UPDATED: I've already read this, but just finished it a 2nd time reading it to my children; doing all the voices and everything! (Note: I finished the ILLUSTRATED VERSION for the 2nd time. I've read book 1 & the rest of the series too many times). THEY LOVED IT! And now they are fixing to watch the first movie. I also found the illustrated version of book 2 "The Chamber of Secrets" (that was just released on 10/4/16). So after they finish the first movie, we will be starting book 2 together! My kids are officially little wizards now and in love with the magical world of Harry Potter! I'm bouncing off the walls with happiness and can't wait to start book 2 with them!<br />5 Stars....always!</span>  <a data-text-id="6734005276447247705" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1491361474"> class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/36087597-aleri?shelf=favoritos2016">favoritos2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1703354670" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4043402287773955847">No puedo creer todo lo que dure para animarme a leer este libro (culpo a las pelU+00EDculas por eso) es probablemente el mejor inicio de saga que he podido leer, sin duda de ese tipo de historias que te marca para toda la vida, creo que si no hubiera pelU+00EDculas el impacto (al menos en mU+00ED) hubiera sido mU+00E1s grande, pero aU+00FAn y con eso lo ame. </span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1703354670">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link1703354670" class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1703354670'><a id="like_count_review_1703354670" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1703354670?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">38 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_1703354670" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_1703354670" ref="like" id='comments_for_review_1703354670' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/1703354670/comments?reverse=true">View 2 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_93980748" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/93980748" />    <a title="Becky" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1376766-becky"><img alt="Becky" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1457393924p2/1376766.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/93980748?book_show_action=false">Dec 16, 2015</a>      <a title="Becky" class="user" name="Becky" href="/user/show/1376766-becky">Becky</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780590353427" href="/book/show/121121.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=owned">owned</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=multi-dimensional">multi-dimensional</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=reviewed">reviewed</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=2010">2010</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1376766-becky?shelf=highly-recommended">highly-recommended</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer93980748" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4411359534207677180">I wasn't sure if I was going to write a review of these books, but I try to write a review of all of the books that I read, and it's been kind of nagging at me that I didn't write one for this. It's hard to write a review for a book that is so dang popular and well known. What is there to say that's new? I dunno. I think pretty much everything's been said, but still I wanted to write a review for this, and to talk about these books, even if I'm just rehashing everything that's already been done.</span>  <span id="freeText4411359534207677180" style="display:none">I wasn't sure if I was going to write a review of these books, but I try to write a review of all of the books that I read, and it's been kind of nagging at me that I didn't write one for this. It's hard to write a review for a book that is so dang popular and well known. What is there to say that's new? I dunno. I think pretty much everything's been said, but still I wanted to write a review for this, and to talk about these books, even if I'm just rehashing everything that's already been done. <br /><br />I remember when these first came out, I never really wanted to read them. I thought of them as "kid's books" and even though I read YA, my overly-critical half just kept saying that these weren't for me. I don't know if it was the cover, or the insta-popularity of the books or what, but I didn't read them. I avoided them like the plague. Until a friend of mine was reading the 5th book, and was so engrossed in it that he would do the "...yes, yes, I'm paying attention..." nod while his eyes remained glued to the page. And as a reader myself, I know that look. So I asked to borrow the book he was reading, and he refused. He told me that if I was going to read it, I'd have to READ it, starting with the first book. So the next day, he lent me the first and second books, both of which I finished in record time, and then I understood. And I never looked back. <br /><br />There's something about these books that is just... magical. Yeah, yeah, cliche, I know. But it's true. Yes, they are about magic, but they are about so much more than that. They are about love, and friendship and loyalty and trust and betrayal and commitment and all the things that we aspire to have and to be as humans. They are about understanding and forgiveness and learning who we are when it really matters. And all of these things are buried in this shell of fun and adventure and mystery that makes them irresistible. <br /><br />I decided to read these again in the original UK editions, because I know that the US editions were "Americanized", and I wanted to re-experience them in their true form. I dislike when things are changed from their original format, I hate abridgments and condensed versions etc. I want to experience the story how the author wrote it, how it was meant to be experienced without some guy in a suit somewhere trying to make it "accessible" to me. I like the feeling that I get of learning something of another culture through the words they use, and the meaning that they give the words. This is why they taught us reading comprehension in third grade, so that we can read and LEARN. Learning doesn't have to be boring and tedious, it can be fun if we allow it to be. But it seems that we've lost that ability. Sad. <br /><br />Anyway, I re-read the first book, now appropriately titled "Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone", and I was surprised at how emotional I felt reading it, especially after knowing where it all ends. It was like seeing friends that you've missed for years again, and while it makes you happy to see them, it's also sad because you know they'll have to go again too soon. That's how I felt, like I was seeing friends and that my time with them is short. That's kind of a silly way to feel, because they are forever, and I can visit anytime I want to, but I felt that way anyway. Especially meeting Ron again. He's my favorite character for an absolute reason, which is because he is so loyal and funny and true, and he gives his whole heart when he gives it at all. I wish that there were more people like Ron. <br /><br />I can't wait to re-read the rest of the series and see if this feeling remains. I love discovering the hidden gems that Rowling has left for us to find, in mythology and history and legend and word-play and in life. Who wouldn't love these books? </span>  <a data-text-id="4411359534207677180" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div id="reviewTextContainer1074664321" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer6169529823574205229">This book was given to me by an english chick in a hostel in Central America. It was supposed to make me want to read the rest of the catalogue; it did not. The worst part of this book is how stupid that stupid wizard game is. How do they not realize they should just save their energy until the end when the one ball that wins the game comes into play? It is infuriating to me that people play this game on quads across the country, a game that is intended to be played while flying on broomsticks.</span>  <span id="freeText6169529823574205229" style="display:none">This book was given to me by an english chick in a hostel in Central America. It was supposed to make me want to read the rest of the catalogue; it did not. The worst part of this book is how stupid that stupid wizard game is. How do they not realize they should just save their energy until the end when the one ball that wins the game comes into play? It is infuriating to me that people play this game on quads across the country, a game that is intended to be played while flying on broomsticks. Why do some children's books make some people think they are big readers because they are able to focus on children's literature. For my time, I will pick up <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/4273.Roald_Dahl" title="Roald Dahl">Roald Dahl</a> any day of the week over this series.</span>  <a  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_594958962" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/594958962" />    <a title="Vane J." class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j"><img alt="Vane J." src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1468102148p2/19590155.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/594958962?book_show_action=false">Dec 22, 2015</a>      <a title="Vane J." class="user" name="Vane J." href="/user/show/19590155-vane-j">Vane J.</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=amazing-characters">amazing-characters</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=2011">2011</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19590155-vane-j?shelf=speshul-snowflake">speshul-snowflake</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer594958962" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4117128937159025094"><b>Edit (December 5, 2015):</b><br><br>First re-read I've ever done in my life. I must say, this book isn't quite the best thing in the world. It has many tropes I <i>really</i> hate (speshul snowflake, villain that only wants to take over the world for no reason, etc), but there's something <i>magical</i> about it and all those aspects for some reason make me smile.<br><br>It's amusing how innocent everything was when it all started. It could fool you into thinking this is just some kid's adventure when really is a journey that wi</span>  <span id="freeText4117128937159025094" style="display:none"><b>Edit (December 5, 2015):</b><br><br>First re-read I've ever done in my life. I must say, this book isn't quite the best thing in the world. It has many tropes I <i>really</i> hate (speshul snowflake, villain that only wants to take over the world for no reason, etc), but there's something <i>magical</i> about it and all those aspects for some reason make me smile.<br><br>It's amusing how innocent everything was when it all started. It could fool you into thinking this is just some kid's adventure when really is a journey that will eat our hearts. <i>Harry Potter</i> is not my favourite series ever, or the one that has affected me the most (that place is saved for <i>The Monstrumologist</i> by Rick Yancey), but certainly it's one of the best and it kind of made my childhood (I grew up with the movies, actually, not with the books, but I was, in any case, attached to the story since a kid). J.K., I'm sorry for saying you're not a goddess in my <i>The Cuckoo's Calling</i> review.<br><br>______________________<br><br><b>There's no way to properly review this thing, so I'm just gonna tell you how I met the Harry Potter series...</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1380222758ra/675051.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>There was a little girl named Vanessa who always wanted to do the contrary to what people wanted her to do. If she had a chore to do, she would do it as long as they let her alone. If mom or dad or one of her brothers or her sister or anyone in her family told her to do it, she would immediately refuse, because she takes no orders. She's her own boss.<br><br>As she was like that, then if something was popular, she would not do/read/watch/whatever it. Well, there was this particular <b>little</b> series that everyone had read. It had movies and everyone loved them.<br><br>Do you know what she did? She promised herself she would <i>never</i> read them. She had already watched the movies (the ones that were out) and she rather liked them, but she would <i>not</i> touch the books, because doing so would mean she was just like everyone else, and she was special (yeah, I was that arrogant).<br><br><b>Some years later.</b><br><br>October 15th, 2011.<br><br>It was a gray day and it was her brother's birthday. Mother wanted to gift his son something that he would enjoy, but not videogames or stuff like that. She wanted something with more educational value - say, a book.<br><br>Mother knew Vanessa's brother liked the HP movies (up until the sixth one), and as there was a book fair at his school (which was mine too), and the books upon which the movies were based were there. She bought the first and gave it to his son for his birthday.<br><br>Some of her mother's friend had also given Vanessa's brother several of the other boks in the series. It seemed as if they had planned the whole thing.<br><br>Of course Vanessa thought there was a hidden purpose there. She thought her mother had bought the books so she wouldn't resist on picking them (I told you I was arrogant, didn't I?).<br><br>She was wrong. That was not her mother's purpose, but in the end, Vanessa couldn't resist the pull. She wanted and didn't want to read the books.<br><br>Wanted them for some reasons:<br><br>U+00B7 She had always been intrigued by them.<br>U+00B7 She was the reader in the house. She couldn't stand the fact that her brother (who hated - and still hates - reading) was going to read more books than her (don't even tell me).<br>U+00B7 A "friend" of hers was bragging she had read the HP books in less than one week and she wanted to prove her she could do the same.<br><br>Didn't want them for some reasons:<br><br>U+00B7 Reading them would mean she was a common girl (I was an insufferable 13-year-old girl - don't blame me).<br>U+00B7 She would break her promise if she read them.<br>U+00B7 If she read them, she would do what everyone else wanted her to do, and as you know, she hates being told what to do.<br><br>After a long time of deep philosophizing (aka one day), she decided she would read them. What could be the worst thing to happen?<br><br>It turns out she loved the first book. Her reaction upon starting it was something like this:<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1384792919ra/6963846.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>After that, she wanted the next ones. She borrowed the books from his brother and read them all up to the 5th one (those were the ones we had) in one week. She felt sorry for not doing it any sooner.<br><br>...<br><br>Yeah, I was and still am like that. I'm really glad I decided to read the books. They all have amazing plots, fantastic character development, writing that improves over the books, great story and world building, etc. What else can I need?<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1430411241i/14710917.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></span>  <a data-text-id="4117128937159025094" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review594958962">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link594958962" title="Flag this review as comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/594958962?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=4">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_594958962' style='display:  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_771541660" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/771541660" />    <a title="Kathe L" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/25921490-kathe-l"><img alt="Kathe L" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1421550107p2/25921490.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/771541660?book_show_action=false">Jun 12, 2015</a>      <a title="Kathe L" class="user" name="Kathe L" href="/user/show/25921490-kathe-l">Kathe L</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25921490-kathe-l?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25921490-kathe-l?shelf=read-more-than-once">read-more-than-once</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25921490-kathe-l?shelf=5-stars">5-stars</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/25921490-kathe-l?shelf=read-2015">read-2015</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer771541660" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1564133102567308804"><b>"There are all kinds of courage," said Dumbledore, smiling."It takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends."</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1423017066ra/13576920.gif" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I love this book, with all my heart. That's why this review is so hard to write. Who has never heard about <i>Harry Potter,</i> the guy who lived? I always say that the <i>The book thief</i> was the first book I have ever read, but then, there's this one. That I read sooo long ago, that I didn't remember a single thing about it. I know <s>all</s> almost</span>  <span id="freeText1564133102567308804" style="display:none"><b>"There are all kinds of courage," said Dumbledore, smiling."It takes a great deal of bravery to stand up to our enemies, but just as much to stand up to our friends."</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1423017066ra/13576920.gif" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I love this book, with all my heart. That's why this review is so hard to write. Who has never heard about <i>Harry Potter,</i> the guy who lived? I always say that the <i>The book thief</i> was the first book I have ever read, but then, there's this one. That I read sooo long ago, that I didn't remember a single thing about it. I know <s>all</s> almost all lines by head because I've watched the movie thousands of times, but there's <b>nothing</b> like reading the book. It's like myself talking to my brother after I finished it:<br><br><b>Me:</b> Gu, (his name is Gustavo - when we went to the USA, nobody understood his name. Is that an unusual name?) did you know that after Ron plays chess, there was another test? A potion one? <br><b>My brother:</b> REALLY? Why wouldn't they show that at the movie? I bet it was amazing, potions and all. Hermione solve it, right? Imagine if I guessed it correctly like her? <br><b>Me:</b> Don't know, Gus. Would you read the book, then? There are thousands of things you will only know about HP if you read it<br><b>My brother:</b> Nah, I hate reading. <br><br><b>My point is:</b> like myself before I reread this, my brother and other people who never read this book and only watched the movie will never know the things that also happened. LIKE HOW MANY TIMES NEVILLE IS PRESENT ON THE SCENES! How Hermione is way geekier, Ginny is SO young, the way Hagrid speaks. And still, there are things that never seizes to amaze me about these books: <b>friendship, loyalty, love, magic.</b> They are present in every page of this, every scene, every line. <br><br>The way Hermione becomes their friend was always one of the things I liked the most. She's so different from Harry and Ron, and still, she fits. She learns, she takes risks, she goes with Ron and Harry in their adventures because she is brave, in her own way. She has a heart of gold, like my mom used to say, just like Harry. <br><br><b>"There are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them."</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1434134341ra/15178418.gif" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I have to talk about Harry, as well. He is just... oh my. He is this eleven year old kid who lived with his mean aunt and uncle for his entire existence to discover that he is , actually, a <b>wizard.</b> So he goes to this school, finds out is famous and that his parents were killed for one of the best bad wizards out there. He doesn't know how to do magic, it's his first time making friends, in an entire new school in a total different environment, and still, he does good. Because he's kind, courageous, strong-minded, smart. He's an excellent friend, an excellent student. (unless when he's not sneaking around lol but still, he does it for the greater good). Harry Potter is not only one of these books you love, it speaks to you. It makes you care about people who are not real, and still, you love them. You have all the dvds, all the books. You watched every movie in the movie theater as soon as they were released. It was a tradition, something you waited the whole year for. <b>And no, you didn't cry like a baby in the last one.</b> Not in Leville's speech, because how has he grown!. Not in Snape's scene, not when Harry "dies." And you definitely didn't cry when the movie ended. It's just... it's a love for a series that will never die, you know? <br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1434134402ra/15178425.gif" width="350" height="300" alt="description" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I loved every aspect of this. I loved how the movie was as faithful as possible, loved the authors playing these characters so well, loved how different and important each one of them is. Snape, Dumbledore, Hermione, Ron, Neville Longbottom, George and Fred, Harry, of course. I just can't wait to read the next one and be mesmerized all over again.<br><br><b>"After all, to the well-organized mind, death is but the next great adventure."</b></span>  <a data-text-id="1564133102567308804" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review771541660">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link771541660" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=771541660&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_771541660'><a id="like_count_review_771541660" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/771541660?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">36 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_771541660" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_771541660" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=36&rating[page]=4&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=771541660&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_771541660" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 771541660, true, &#39;&#39;); rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2431873-emily?shelf=ya-fiction">ya-fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/2431873-emily?shelf=childrens-books">childrens-books</a>,               <a href="/review/list/2431873-emily?shelf=sci-fi-fantasy">sci-fi-fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer515990587" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer5899302369964533300">It's impossible not to date myself through this review, but I first read Harry Potter when I was young enough to wish for a Hogwarts letter of my own. I'm now rereading the exact same hardcovers that I bought as they were released, mostly because my mother is a saint and mailed them all to me in San Francisco:<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1465015742i/19303416.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm rereading this book while drinking a glass of wine (HA!!), and on this pass I really think it's the optimal children's book. It opens an entire world while still following a compact, in</span>  <span id="freeText5899302369964533300" style="display:none">It's impossible not to date myself through this review, but I first read Harry Potter when I was young enough to wish for a Hogwarts letter of my own. I'm now rereading the exact same hardcovers that I bought as they were released, mostly because my mother is a saint and mailed them all to me in San Francisco:<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1465015742i/19303416.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I'm rereading this book while drinking a glass of wine (HA!!), and on this pass I really think it's the optimal children's book. It opens an entire world while still following a compact, interesting plot, and it makes me laugh on every single page. It's amazing that the Dumbledore who says, at the first feast, "Nitwit! Blubber! Oddment! Tweak!" can be the same person as the Dumbledore of the rest of the series, but somehow that is believable and wonderful. <br><br>5/5 this book made me cry happy tears but maybe it was the alcohol</span>  <a data-text-id="5899302369964533300" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_73108717" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/73108717" />    <a title="Justin" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/2795921-justin"><img alt="Justin" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1470601743p2/2795921.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/73108717?book_show_action=false">Nov 05, 2015</a>      <a title="Justin" class="user" name="Justin" href="/user/show/2795921-justin">Justin</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer73108717" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15356904741898629585">Rather than write a review of this book, I will instead share memories I have about the series.<br /><br />*Making fun of my high school girlfriend for reading the books, borrowing this one from her, sitting in a chair in my parents' office and reading the first few pages, and apologizing for ever making fun of her. I was hooked.<br /><br />*Working at a bookstore when Order of the Phoenix was released and dressing up like Harry Potter. I danced around in the middle of the mall with a copy of the book to remind everyon</span>  <span id="freeText15356904741898629585" style="display:none">Rather than write a review of this book, I will instead share memories I have about the series.<br /><br />*Making fun of my high school girlfriend for reading the books, borrowing this one from her, sitting in a chair in my parents' office and reading the first few pages, and apologizing for ever making fun of her. I was hooked.<br /><br />*Working at a bookstore when Order of the Phoenix was released and dressing up like Harry Potter. I danced around in the middle of the mall with a copy of the book to remind everyone that it was finally out, and also to embarrass myself.<br /><br />*Visiting Universal Studios as an adult and riding all the Harry Potter rides, drinking butterbeer, and taking a picture outside the Hogwarts Express<br /><br />*Receiving a Gryffindor scarf as a Christmas gift from my grandparents-in-law<br /><br /><br />Obviously, this book and series are amazing and giving it anything less than five stars is ridiculous. </span>  <a data-text-id="15356904741898629585" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review73108717">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link73108717" title="Flag this review as id="reviewTextContainer468114983" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14917426670349043203"><b>When you re-read a book and you get goosebumps from reading certain parts...</b> <3<br /><br />I will forever love this series which was a huge part of my childhood and early teenage years. I have forgotten how many times I have re-read these books by now, but I like finally being able to re-read it all in English. <b>So different yet the same, and oh so wonderful.</b> I'm very much looking forward to the rest of the books!<br /><br /><blockquote> <i>"He couldn't know that at this very moment, people meeting in secret all over the country we</i></blockquote></span>  <span id="freeText14917426670349043203" style="display:none"><b>When you re-read a book and you get goosebumps from reading certain parts...</b> <3<br /><br />I will forever love this series which was a huge part of my childhood and early teenage years. I have forgotten how many times I have re-read these books by now, but I like finally being able to re-read it all in English. <b>So different yet the same, and oh so wonderful.</b> I'm very much looking forward to the rest of the books!<br /><br /><blockquote>  <i>"He couldn't know that at this very moment, people meeting in secret all over the country were holding up their glasses and saying in hushed voices: 'To Harry Potter -- the boy who lived!'"</i></blockquote></span>  <a data-text-id="14917426670349043203" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> id="reviewTextContainer1556284845" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12338570422743232187">I have been richly rewarded for waiting all these years to read this - what an indulgence to be able to read the new illustrated version for my first Potter book. It's brilliant! I especially love the incredibly soulful sketch of Harry on page 238.<br /><br />Loved this, all of it - but no point in reviewing and remarking on what the world already knows. If you are a fan and haven't perused the Jim Kay illustrated volume yet, you really must. It's a masterpiece. I hope they do all the volumes, but I'm not w</span>  <span id="freeText12338570422743232187" style="display:none">I have been richly rewarded for waiting all these years to read this - what an indulgence to be able to read the new illustrated version for my first Potter book. It's brilliant! I especially love the incredibly soulful sketch of Harry on page 238.<br /><br />Loved this, all of it - but no point in reviewing and remarking on what the world already knows. If you are a fan and haven't perused the Jim Kay illustrated volume yet, you really must. It's a masterpiece. I hope they do all the volumes, but I'm not waiting any longer to read the rest of them! class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer13079767656184460896">Obviously a re-read for me.<br /><br />Loved reading this book for the second time and having the illustrated version be the edition to experience it all again. Rowling is such a master storyteller. Not many writers have achieved creating such beloved characters. The illustrations were beautiful and that close to ending scene with Dumbledore is perfection. So much love and detail was put into these unique characters. <br /><br />Hagrid, I will always love you. </span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> id="reviewTextContainer1160974248" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer12217224735672003065">As always, this story feels like coming home.<br><br>A noteworthy development: This is the first time I've cried reading book one. I'm always prepared to cry while reading five and seven, but this was unexpected to say the least, especially given the countless number of times I've read this book. The Mirror of Erised scene just really hit me this time around. And I really appreciate Chris Columbus and Steve Kloves for making such a faithful film adaptation. This book remains pure magic.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1380352348ra/705811.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>update: HAHA I ju</span>  <span id="freeText12217224735672003065" style="display:none">As always, this story feels like coming home.<br><br>A noteworthy development: This is the first time I've cried reading book one. I'm always prepared to cry while reading five and seven, but this was unexpected to say the least, especially given the countless number of times I've read this book. The Mirror of Erised scene just really hit me this time around. And I really appreciate Chris Columbus and Steve Kloves for making such a faithful film adaptation. This book remains pure magic.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1380352348ra/705811.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><br>update: HAHA I just finished this only to have Doc pick it up. <br><br>1/6/16<br>He's only 8 pages in but he already hates the Dursleys more than he already did from watching the films (and lemme tell you, he despised them to begin with). He especially detests Uncle Vernon. He also says he never got the vibe from the films of how utterly paranoid they are regarding magic and the Potters.<br><br>1/13/16<br>He still loves the zoo boa constrictor's "Thankssss, amigo."<br>Also, "YER A WIZARD, HARRY."<br><br>1/21/16<br>He really gets a kick out of the way Hagrid speaks, he says it sounds like he's from Appalachia -- coming off reading Spencer's Mountain, it seems to be a good grounding point. And he picked up on Fantastic Beasts in the list of course books, and liked that I have the little copy of that one downstairs too :) Oh and he says he must not have paid much attention to the movie before, because the twin cores thing between Harry's and Voldy's wands really got his attention. <br><br>Also, George's line: "We'll send you a Hogwarts toilet seat!" to which I had to respond "<i>George!</i> -- Only joking, Mum." And then he just stared at me with the face of Who-even-are-you.<br><br>I am LOVING this.<br><br>3/1/16<br>He finished it a few days ago (maybe it's been a week now?) and is on to book two. This edition has a sneak peek of the next book in the back, and he started reading that the other night before stopping and saying "Hang on, the second book's downstairs. Why am I reading this when I can just go get the book??" ROFL.</span>  <a data-text-id="12217224735672003065" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons"> itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1005274201" />    <a title="nancy" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/10265533-nancy"><img alt="nancy" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1455242332p2/10265533.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1005274201?book_show_action=false">Dec 31, 2015</a>      <a title="nancy" class="user" name="nancy" href="/user/show/10265533-nancy">nancy</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/10265533-nancy?shelf=own">own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1005274201" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14862725625748613297">Absolutely amazing! I don't know why it took me so long to start this series but I'm so glad I finally did. There are so many scenes in the book that were left out of the movie completely that I'm glad I got to experience by reading the book. I can't wait to jump into the second book of Potter's journey!</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11378054093795203823">June 2016 - Rereading my all time favorite series is the BEST. EVER. Even up to this day, it never lose its charm. My reading journey started on this series and it will always remained in my heart. I feel so nostalgic. If you haven't read this series, it's never too late. :) <br /><br />Potterhead forever <3. [and still waiting for my Hogwarts letter] </span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1454172046" />    <a title="Melanie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie"><img alt="Melanie" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1474399332p2/3030788.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1454172046?book_show_action=false">Jun 15, 2016</a>      <a title="Melanie" class="user" name="Melanie" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie">Melanie</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780545790352" href="/book/show/24490481-harry-potter-and-the-sorcerer-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=read-in-2015">read-in-2015</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=witches">witches</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=buddy-reads">buddy-reads</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1454172046" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer14170127663113257197"><i> U+201CIt does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.U+201D </i><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449418721i/17283305._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I've sat at my desk for over an hour and I still, after all these years, do not think I can review this book properly. All I can say is that <i>Harry Potter</i> feels like home, and every page of this book feels like magic; and not the magic that has to do with wizards or Hogwarts, but magic that has to do with love that is all encompassing. <br><br>This book was published nearly twenty years ago, but when I opened this book to the first page it felt lik</span>  <span id="freeText14170127663113257197" style="display:none"><i> U+201CIt does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.U+201D </i><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449418721i/17283305._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>I've sat at my desk for over an hour and I still, after all these years, do not think I can review this book properly. All I can say is that <i>Harry Potter</i> feels like home, and every page of this book feels like magic; and not the magic that has to do with wizards or Hogwarts, but magic that has to do with love that is all encompassing. <br><br>This book was published nearly twenty years ago, but when I opened this book to the first page it felt like not a day had passed. I really don't have any amount of words that I can string together to tell you how this book makes me feel. J.K. Rowling will always set the bar for how a series <i>should</i> be written, because <i>Harry Potter</i> is written with love, and it makes all the difference. <b>Always.</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449029406ra/17225575.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>If you'd like to participate in #HARRYXMASTOYOU here is the official <a href="https://twitter.com/harryxmastoyou" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> and <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BjealyQA-OI" rel="nofollow">YouTube Video</a> for more information! <br><br>Extra Harry Potter things that make me happy and probably will make you happy as well: <br>1.) <a href="http://www.buzzfeed.com/andyneuenschwander/these-adorable-harry-potter-comics-imagine-james-and-lily-as#.xue9RPjL3" rel="nofollow">James And Lily Comics</a><br>2.) <a href="http://www.buzzfeed.com/eleanorbate/pleaseneveraskmethatoneagain#.iiXWMNzlqm" rel="nofollow">New Things J.K. Rowling Taught Us About Harry Potter In 2015</a><br>3.) <a href="http://ohwitchplease.ca/" rel="nofollow">A fortnightly podcast about the Harry Potter world</a><br><br><a href="https://meltotheany.wordpress.com/" rel="nofollow">Blog</a> | <a href="https://www.twitter.com/meltotheany" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="http://meltotheany.tumblr.com/" rel="nofollow">Tumblr</a> | <a href="https://www.instagram.com/meltotheany/" rel="nofollow">Instagram</a> | <a href="https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC4RbHEg_fH6CewJrh_0xJ9g" rel="nofollow">Youtube</a> | <a href="http://www.twitch.tv/meltotheany/profile" rel="nofollow">Twitch</a></span>  <a data-text-id="14170127663113257197" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return firstReview">      <div id="review_1012980854" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1012980854" />    <a title="Eric Boot" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/33117741-eric-boot"><img alt="Eric Boot" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1464627091p2/33117741.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1012980854?book_show_action=false">Aug 16, 2016</a>      <a title="Eric Boot" class="user" name="Eric Boot" href="/user/show/33117741-eric-boot">Eric Boot</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9780747532743" href="/book/show/72193.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=favs-of-all-times">favs-of-all-times</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=re-read">re-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=review">review</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=5-stars-totally-freaking-out">5-stars-totally-freaking-out</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/33117741-eric-boot?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1012980854" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9391483479367696138">I realize many people have said this and many people can express this way better than I can, but I'll try. I don't know how many times I've read the books so far in my life (I guess around the 5 times) but every time I start reading this series again I realize why this is my favourite series ever (and I'm 99.9% sure it will be never surpassed). I have tried to explain this to others, but I never quite manage to tell why I love these books so much. And I don't know what the Nobel Prize comitee is</span>  <span id="freeText9391483479367696138" style="display:none">I realize many people have said this and many people can express this way better than I can, but I'll try. I don't know how many times I've read the books so far in my life (I guess around the 5 times) but every time I start reading this series again I realize why this is my favourite series ever (and I'm 99.9% sure it will be never surpassed). I have tried to explain this to others, but I never quite manage to tell why I love these books so much. And I don't know what the Nobel Prize comitee is thinking but if there is one person who changed the world by books it's J.K. Rowling. There are many other really, really good books, but if I try to compare them to Harry Potter it mostly goes sth like this:<br /><br />Books I like:<br /><b>1. Harry Potter</b><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />2. The other books <br /><i>(Including Percy Jackson, Throne of Glass and The Mortal Instruments) </i><br /><br />(This is so hard :/ I can't do this)<br /><br /><u>when reading 'normal' books, it often goes as follows:</u><br />I read one hour, then I go on Goodreads/YouTube/I watch the news/whatever for some time (like an hour), I pick up the book again etc. <br /><u>when I'm reading Harry Potter things go more like this:</u><br />I read for 3 hours, then I'm like oh I need to check the news, I watch the news for 5 minutes and I'm like <i>but what am I actually doing? This is nonsense I'D RATHER BE READING</i> <br /><br />And that makes that I can read 5 pretty big books in just one week and feel like I should have read more. <br /><br />And at the same time it makes me ache because I know I've only got two books left. <br /><br />AHHHHHHHHHH<br /><br /><i>(time for another reread)</i><br /></span>  <a data-text-id="9391483479367696138" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/768014819" />    <a title="Kelly (and the Book Boar)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/11183856-kelly-and-the-book-boar"><img alt="Kelly (and the Book Boar)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1473347824p2/11183856.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/768014819?book_show_action=false">Nov 19, 2013</a>      <a title="Kelly (and the Book Boar)" class="user" name="Kelly (and the Book Boar)" href="/user/show/11183856-kelly-and-the-book-boar">Kelly (and the Book Boar)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11183856-kelly-and-the-book-boar?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/11183856-kelly-and-the-book-boar?shelf=read-in-2013">read-in-2013</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" id="reviewTextContainer768014819" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3752693058712163103">There is no way I could <b>EVER</b> write a review for this book, so I'm just going to say a few words and leave it at that . . . <br><br><a target="_blank" title="ImageShack - Image And Video Hosting" href="http://imageshack.us/photo/my-images/855/q8g.gif/" I can't believe it's been 15 years since I last touched these pages. "It was the best [re-read of my] life, better than winning at Quidditch, or Christmas, or knocking out mountain trolls . . . [I will] never, ever forget."</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_226968334" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/226968334" />    <a title="Olivia McCloskey" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6767471-olivia-mccloskey"><img alt="Olivia McCloskey" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1455329655p2/6767471.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/226968334?book_show_action=false">Sep 12, 2016</a>      <a title="Olivia McCloskey" class="user" name="Olivia McCloskey" href="/user/show/6767471-olivia-mccloskey">Olivia McCloskey</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=all-time-favorites">all-time-favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=recommended">recommended</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=adventure">adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=all-time-favorite-series">all-time-favorite-series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=get-it-right-away">get-it-right-away</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6767471-olivia-mccloskey?shelf=boarding-school">boarding-school</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer226968334" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer8428290460398215643">"Happiness can be found in the darkest of times, if only one remembers to turn on the light."<br /><br />Since 1997, the Harry Potter series has enchanted readers, both young and old. Legendary British author, J.K. Rowling's debut novel has gained international acclaim since its initial publication, winning a total of seven awards. Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the thrilling first installment of the series where all of the magic began. <br /><br />The novel begins at the small, quiet house on Number Four Pri</span>  <span id="freeText8428290460398215643" style="display:none">"Happiness can be found in the darkest of times, if only one remembers to turn on the light."<br /><br />Since 1997, the Harry Potter series has enchanted readers, both young and old. Legendary British author, J.K. Rowling's debut novel has gained international acclaim since its initial publication, winning a total of seven awards. Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is the thrilling first installment of the series where all of the magic began. <br /><br />The novel begins at the small, quiet house on Number Four Privet Drive, Little Whinging, Surrey where the book's eleven year-old protagonist, Harry Potter, lives in the cupboard under the stairs. He was orphaned at a young age after his parents were killed in a tragic accident and was sent to live with the Dursleys: Aunt Petunia, Uncle Vernon, and their son, Dudley. His only living relatives treat him poorly, making Harry's childhood miserable.<br /><br />Harry's unhappy demeanor is replaced by one of elation when he receives a letter inviting him to attend Hogwarts School of Witchcraft and Wizardry, the finest school for witches and wizards in all of Britain. As the novel unfolds, Harry begins his first year at Hogwarts where he is introduced to the wizarding world, befriends other students, and comes face-to-face with adversity. The twists and turns, mounting suspense, and thrilling perils that Harry encounters render this book life-changning and unforgettable.<br /><br />Rowling has a rare talent for creating believable, realistic characters that gradually change as the story progresses. These characters, as some people would say, possess a certain amount of depth. Their unique personalities and traits distinguish them from the characters in similar novels. Harry embodies all of the characteristics of a true hero: courage, tenacity, and an inclination to protect others. Harry is willing to sacrifice everything, including his own life, to ensure the safety of others. Rowling accurately captures his desire to protect those he loves, whatever the cost.<br /><br />I must admit, Rowling's imagination is extraordinary. Her original vision of a young boy sporting a lighting scar who attended boarding school was transformed into a seven book series teeming with the unimaginable. Rowling's creative prowess enabled her to establish an entirely new world filled with realistic people, magical creatures, and thrilling enchantments. The wizarding world was crafted so thoroughly that it is flawless. No minor detail of this alternate world was excluded, allowing readers to fully immerse themselves in the book.<br /><br />As the plot unfolded, readers received a glimpse of the growing complexity of the series. Rowling introduced specific details throughout the novel which the majority of readers overlook. These seemingly insignificant details, however, have a large impact upon later events within the book. My predictions of the events to come were quite far from the actual events that transpired. The shocking conclusion left me stunned and begging my mother to drive me to Barnes and Noble to purchase the second book.<br /><br />While Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone falls under the "Fantasy" genre, Rowling discretely incorporated many mythological and historical references into the novel, especially those pertaining to the works of Ancient Rome. First and foremost among these allusions is Hagrid's three-headed dog, Fluffy. The concept of such a creature is taken from Greek Mythology; according to legend, Cerberus, a three-headed dog, ferociously guarded the entrance to the Underworld. The only means of subduing Cerberus (and Fluffy, consequently) is the playing of a lyre. Additionally, the Hogwarts motto, "Draco Dormiens Nunquam Titillandus," is Latin for "Never tickle a sleeping dragon." Rowling relies heavily on her knowledge of Latin to create incantations and character names throughout the series.<br /><br />I am most impressed not with the books themselves, but with the author whose rags-to-riches life story has inspired countless people worldwide. J.K. Rowling was born Joanne Kathleen Rowling into a poor family living in Gloucestershire, England. She was accepted at the University of Exeter, where she studied Classics. She was devastated when her mother died shortly after her graduation, having suffered from multiple sclerosis. Several years later, Rowling married Jorge Arantes and gave birth to their daughter, Jessica. The unhappy couple separated 13 months after their marriage. Homeless, penniless, and caring for a newborn, Rowling struggled with depression and contemplated suicide. We almost lost the brilliant, talented mind who is solely responsible for the series that has now become a worldwide phenomenon. Her rags to riches story inspires millions of people in similar situations. Despite her challenges, Rowling's perseverance and determination brought the world of Harry Potter to life.<br /><br />Overall, this series is the most memorable from my childhood. I was originally introduced to the series in third grade and immediately fell in love with the realistic characters, suspenseful plot, and flawless writing style. I was the diehard fan who watched each movie a dozen times at the same movie theater, eventually coming to know the employees at the concessions stand on a first name basis. For Halloween last year, in fact, I dressed up in an old pair of robes, pulled on a wig, and drew a scar on my forehead. And to this day, I find myself reciting quotes from the series. I was crushed after the release of the final book, feeling that part of my childhood had ended with the series. Looking back, I have never once regretted the time I have spent reading and rereading the series, committing it to memory. The Harry Potter series has served as more than a way to pass the time; it has helped to shape the person I am today.</span>  <a data-text-id="8428290460398215643" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review226968334">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link226968334" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=226968334&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_226968334'><a id="like_count_review_226968334" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/226968334?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">32 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_226968334" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_226968334" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=32&rating[page]=5&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=226968334&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_226968334" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 226968334, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">3 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/226968334?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=5">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_226968334' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/226968334/comments?reverse=true">View all 3 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div></div><div class='brown_comment' id='comments_form_review_226968334' style='display: none'><textarea class='placeholder_text' onclick="expand_comment_form_for('review', 226968334, true, '')">Write a comment...</textarea></div>  </td></tr>      </div>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div>    </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_451290584" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/451290584" />    <a title="Christopher" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/14386596-christopher"><img alt="Christopher" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1402231159p2/14386596.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/451290584?book_show_action=false">Jun 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Christopher" class="user" name="Christopher" href="/user/show/14386596-christopher">Christopher</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=fiction">fiction</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=kindle-unlimited">kindle-unlimited</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=adventure">adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=buddy-read">buddy-read</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/14386596-christopher?shelf=2016">2016</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer451290584" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15558883151130064846">There's a decent chance you won't like this book. <br /><br />Let's be honest here. If you're reading my reviews and haven't read this series, you're probably an adult, which means two things. One is that you have lived through this series releasing 7 novels, 8 movies, and becoming a cultural phenomenon. If you're here, you felt that societal pressure to read this, or one of your friends won't shut up until you do (probably). There is little chance the hype can withstand reality. <br /><br />And that is partly because.</span>  <span id="freeText15558883151130064846" style="display:none">There's a decent chance you won't like this book. <br /><br />Let's be honest here. If you're reading my reviews and haven't read this series, you're probably an adult, which means two things. One is that you have lived through this series releasing 7 novels, 8 movies, and becoming a cultural phenomenon. If you're here, you felt that societal pressure to read this, or one of your friends won't shut up until you do (probably). There is little chance the hype can withstand reality. <br /><br />And that is partly because... you aren't eleven years old. This book is written for children. Yes, the books get darker and more mature (and much better) later on, but this one is for middle school aged kids.<br /><br />This is my first time rereading book 1 in at least 6 years. This book commits sins I would never forgive if they occurred in a different book. The main characters are dumb, the authority figures should all be fired for child endangerment, and in order for some events to make any sense, one has to create their own head-canon. Typically at such points, I stop, remind myself that this is a children's book, and get a glass of Maker's 46.<br /><br />But forgive them I do. Rowling creates a fantastic world, characters, and story over these seven books that makes it all worth it. If I were reading this for the first time today, I honestly do not know if I would DNF this due to the above sins or simply for it targeting a much different audience than adult me. But I do know that having read the rest of the series, it didn't even cross my mind not to finish this reread, despite seeing all of the problems. The writing is designed so the target audience ages with Harry, so while we never get adult novels, we do get much "better" writing in later books. If you read this book or even the first two and the writing is much of what turned you off, I encourage you to keep going for another couple of books.<br /><br /><br /><br />As a final note, my rating for this book is for the series. I can't honestly rate this book by itself at this point.</span>  <a data-text-id="15558883151130064846" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review451290584">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1536987673" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1536987673" />    <a title="Tracey (YA Book Addict)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/4748843-tracey-ya-book-addict"><img alt="Tracey (YA Book Addict)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1454928266p2/4748843.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1536987673?book_show_action=false">Mar 13, 2016</a>      <a title="Tracey (YA Book Addict)" class="user" name="Tracey (YA Book Addict)" href="/user/show/4748843-tracey-ya-book-addict">Tracey (YA Book Addict)</a>          added it          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Paperback 9781408855652" href="/book/show/22841994-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1536987673" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9929834086164815645">I first picked up The Philosopher's Stone about seven years ago. I'd gone from reading true crime and biographies, to having just finished the Twilight saga, when the Harry Potter series was recommended to me. From memory I think I read the first two chapters and then put it down. It felt really young and I felt it just wasn't for me. So I moved on. After starting my IG account I was constantly bombarded with people telling me how amazing the series was and how I had to read it. I'm not even</span>  <span id="freeText9929834086164815645" style="display:none">I first picked up The Philosopher's Stone about seven years ago. I'd gone from reading true crime and biographies, to having just finished the Twilight saga, when the Harry Potter series was recommended to me. From memory I think I read the first two chapters and then put it down. It felt really young and I felt it just wasn't for me. So I moved on. After starting my IG account I was constantly bombarded with people telling me how amazing the series was and how I had to read it. I'm not even sure why I decided to give it another try, but I did. And it just goes to show that even if a book is not meant for you when you first pick it up, it doesn't mean that at another time it won't be something that you love. Because this book... This book was brilliant! It was enchanting and captivating and magical. I was completely engrossed from the very first page. I absolutely adored the friendship between Harry and Ron, and the dynamic was completed once Hermione was accepted into the little group. And Hermione, boy she was awesome! She had me grinning from ear to ear. I'm so intrigued by Snape, and I can't wait to peel back all his layers to see what he has hidden. And then there's the gentle giant that is Hagrid. My heart is so full of love for him. My favourite character so far! I can't tell you how incredibly happy I am to have given this series a second chance. I can now officially say I'm well on my way to being a Potterhead! </span>  <a data-text-id="9929834086164815645" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>
