</div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1589985572" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1589985572" />    <a title="Brian" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1938805-brian"><img alt="Brian" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442608867p2/1938805.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1589985572?book_show_action=false">Jul 18, 2016</a>      <a title="Brian" class="user" name="Brian" href="/user/show/1938805-brian">Brian</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">liked it</span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1938805-brian?shelf=read_with_bel">read_with_bel</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1589985572" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1785899583763076740">It wasnU+2019t much of a shock when the world learned, upon the completion of the Harry Potter octology, that J.K. Rowling was formerly a high ranking agent in MI6. In the early U+201890s the UK was just emerging from the shadow of Thatcherism and a dozen years of painful domestic reform; the Soviet Union had issued its dying fetid breath and the resulting power vacuum offered a unique opportunity for the country to return to its former glory. RowlingU+2019s memoranda and comminiquU+00E9 had always leaned towards</span>  <span id="freeText1785899583763076740" style="display:none">It wasnU+2019t much of a shock when the world learned, upon the completion of the Harry Potter octology, that J.K. Rowling was formerly a high ranking agent in MI6. In the early U+201890s the UK was just emerging from the shadow of Thatcherism and a dozen years of painful domestic reform; the Soviet Union had issued its dying fetid breath and the resulting power vacuum offered a unique opportunity for the country to return to its former glory. RowlingU+2019s memoranda and comminiquU+00E9 had always leaned towards the florid; she was the natural choice when the nationU+2019s intelligence agency decided to U+201CretireU+201D one of their most decorated agents and move her into a new role. It turned out to be one of the greatest propaganda coups in Western Civilization.<br /><br />The formerly defunct MI7, created specifically in the early 1900s for the type of work Rowling would be asked to do, was clandestinely revived with the resources to support a lone agent with a singular purpose: create a new British hero. What they did not want was a James Bond reboot - a cavalier, womanizing anti-hero that righted the worldU+2019s ills at the draw of a gun. The new world required a new kind of icon, someone with whom the pre-teens of the U+201890s could relate. U+201CIU+2019ve got this,U+201D Rowling was rumored to have said. A classic understatement, in every sense.<br /><br />Book One of the Potter series establishes all of the important tropes and themes that any propogandist worth her salt would employ. Rowling even put her prowess at anagrams to good use. Harry Potter: <i>Try Hero Part</i>. HarryU+2019s feckless aunt, representing the American hegemony, is a personal favorite. Petunia Darsley: <i>Easily Upturned</i>. Potter is the offspring of two famous practitioners of magic, their deaths representative of the twin pasts of former British rule: supremacy of international commerce and the resulting colonialism. The young Harry doesnU+2019t know about his past - he must learn about it in a classic unfolding narrative that reveals how special he (i.e. the UK) really is. The tutelage and mentorship of Hogwarts has been shown to be a thinly veiled allusion to the European Union. Online chatrooms and water cooler discussions over the past 20 years have been filled with opinions on which EU member is represented by Dumbledore, McGonagall, Snape, etc. - suffice to say that it is another testament to RowlingU+2019s brilliance that she has never offered any opinions to the discussions; allowing the punters their pet views, however misguided, only strengthened the allegory.<br /><br />It is said that the creation of the storyU+2019s villain was RowlingU+2019s most difficult task. To take on the USA directly, the UKU+2019s closest ally and the last global power, was strictly off limits. Still, that didnU+2019t stop the speculation that America was indeed the antagonist (the whole U+201CdonU+2019t-speak-his-nameU+201D thing taken too literal), but as declassified documents have shown, RowlingU+2019s intention from the start was for Voldemort to be the representation of all the evilU+2019s of British past, for if the UK was to ever achieve its new ascendancy, it must first not be afraid to speak - and acknowledge - its former horrors; it must learn from those mistakes and grow strong with the help of its new world allies in hope of one day achieving that new Golden Age of the British Empire.</span>  <a data-text-id="1785899583763076740" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1589985572">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow"      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1589985572'><a id="like_count_review_1589985572" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1589985572?resource_type=Review"><span comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/1589985572?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=9">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_1589985572' style='display: class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1509387951?book_show_action=false">Feb 08, 2016</a>      <a title="Vicky (the Blowtorch-Wielding OotCDCBU+2122)" class="user" name="Vicky (the Blowtorch-Wielding OotCDCBU+2122)" href="/user/show/21619434-vicky-the-blowtorch-wielding-ootcdcb">Vicky (the Blowtorch-Wielding OotCDCBU+2122)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408845646" href="/book/show/24548235-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21619434-vicky-the-blowtorch-wielding-ootcdcb?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21619434-vicky-the-blowtorch-wielding-ootcdcb?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21619434-vicky-the-blowtorch-wielding-ootcdcb?shelf=cover-luv">cover-luv</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/21619434-vicky-the-blowtorch-wielding-ootcdcb?shelf=2016-reads">2016-reads</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1509387951" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer3489737534202265966">From time to time I play a <i>"What if?"</i> game with my sister <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Yes, we're both adults <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<i>Sort of.</i> Shut up :P <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> and at some point we'll ask ourselves: <i> <b>"What if your house was burning down and you could <s>save</s> take only one book on your way out?"</b> </i> <u>JUST ONE.</u> <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Why we find this entertaining is beyond me. I've stopped trying to understand my own weirdness by now. Just go with it. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454890227i/18026669._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>This is <i>obviously</i> not a decision I take lig</span>  <span id="freeText3489737534202265966" style="display:none">From time to time I play a <i>"What if?"</i> game with my sister <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Yes, we're both adults <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[<i>Sort of.</i> Shut up :P <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span> and at some point we'll ask ourselves: <i>  <b>"What if your house was burning down and you could <s>save</s> take only one book on your way out?"</b></i> <u>JUST ONE.</u> <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Why we find this entertaining is beyond me. I've stopped trying to understand my own weirdness by now. Just go with it. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454890227i/18026669._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br>This is <i>obviously</i> not a decision I take lightly. The mere thought of all my beautiful books burning... *shudders* *takes a deep breath*<br>As of today... <a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SAdwKgLaDfM&list=PLNAmsbU7KCu7wk8zNpkpeUCTVKPdt3fxH&index=11" rel="nofollow">(Can I get a drum-roll, please?)</a> <b>THIS</b> beautiful edition of <i>Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</i> is <b>THE ONE.</b> The one I'd chose to save above all others. *gasp*<br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454890636i/18026693._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><blockquote>  <b>The illustrations are simply stunning.</b>  <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454890187i/18026667._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"></blockquote><br><b>J.Kay made me fall in love with JKR's story all over again.</b><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454890863i/18026699.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454892220i/18026826.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><b>I actually hugged the book when I turned the last page.</b> <a class="jsShowSpoiler spoilerAction">(view spoiler)</a><span class="spoilerContainer" style="display: none">[Again, just go with it. <a class="jsHideSpoiler spoilerAction">(hide spoiler)</a>]</span><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454889906i/18026656.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg">--<img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1454889906i/18026655.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><blockquote>  <b>Quite simply, this is a book I'll treasure forever.</b></blockquote><br>********************************************<br>< b>Jan. 14th, 2016. Before reading:<br><br>This beauty arrived in the mail today. It was a reaaally late Christmas present.<br><br>My first reaction: I cried because I'd just heard the news about Alan Rickman, and how twisted is it that 3 weeks after this was ordered it would arrive TODAY of all days?<br><br>Now a few hours have passed and I finally opened it and it is so GORGEOUS and PERFECT and I'm starting to get really excited to do a slow re-read of this book, and admire all the absolutely STUNNING illustrations. SOON!</["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></["br"]></span>  <a data-text-id="3489737534202265966" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));;          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: $('box').getStyle('z-index')})});        } else {          $$('div.prototip').each(function(i){i.setStyle({zIndex: 6000})});        }      });      $('rating_details_tip').observe('prototip:hidden', function () {        $$('span.Two').each(function (e) {          if (e.getStyle('display') !== 'none') {            var lessLink = e.next();            swapContent(lessLink);          }        });      });//]]></script>  <script type="text/javascript">  //<![CDATA[      var $ratingGraph = $j('#rating_graph');      var $copy; href="/review/list/45532677-m-stafy?shelf=read-in-english">read-in-english</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/45532677-m-stafy?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9358891040601519734"><i>[OK since no one really reads my reviews, I'm gonna write as long as I want, nobody cares!]</i><br /><br /><b>Likes: </b><br /><b>U+2022 Characters</b> (Usually everyone in a story has the same personality as the author. But this book had different types of people which was cool!)<br /><b>U+2022 Storyline</b> (it was pretty complicated and therefore it was really awesome!)<br /><b>U+2022 Some ideas</b> (many big ideas or small details in the story that made it wonderful)<br /><b>U+2022 Writing style</b> (so friendly, and sometimes funny)<br /><b>U+2022 Atmosphere</b> (London, an old castle near a mysteriou</span>  <span id="freeText9358891040601519734" style="display:none"><i>[OK since no one really reads my reviews, I'm gonna write as long as I want, nobody cares!]</i><br /><br /><b>U+25FELikes: </b><br /><b>U+2022 Characters</b> (Usually everyone in a story has the same personality as the author. But this book had different types of people which was cool!)<br /><b>U+2022 Storyline</b> (it was pretty complicated and therefore it was really awesome!)<br /><b>U+2022 Some ideas</b> (many big ideas or small details in the story that made it wonderful)<br /><b>U+2022 Writing style</b> (so friendly, and sometimes funny)<br /><b>U+2022 Atmosphere</b> (London, an old castle near a mysterious forest, where people learn magic... It's no wonder lots of people love it and many authors have tried to write a story like it!)<br /><br /><b>U+25FDDislikes:</b><br /><b>U+2022 Harry's character</b> (honestly, I couldn't figure out what kind of a boy he was. Sometimes he's a loser who runs away from the bullies, sometimes he's a hero everyone expects him to be, sometimes he's afraid of saying a word, sometimes he dares to fight Voldemort...)<br /><b>U+2022 Plot holes</b> (I think there's no need to write about the many big black holes in the plot!)<br /><b>U+2022 Wizards' world</b> (I expected the wizards' world to be different. I didn't expect them to educate in schools like the real schools, or play basketball on brooms, or play chess with alive pieces, or have a ministry, or hospitals or a bank. Everything was like the real world with a little difference. It wasn't magical enough.)<br /><b>U+2022 Muggles</b> (this book tells us that magic is so cool, and Muggles are useless and dumb. And I, the reader, AM A MUGGLE! It's just insulting me!)<br /><b>U+2022 Long chapters</b> (the chapters weren't exactly loooong, but I couldn't read the story as fast as other books for some reason, and every time I checked how much more till the next chapter, and saw OMG there's still 10 pages to go!!)</span>  <a data-text-id="9358891040601519734" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1410869250" />    <a title="Christine (weereader)" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/39719286-christine-weereader"><img alt="Christine (weereader)" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1467736668p2/39719286.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1410869250?book_show_action=false">Nov 26, 2015</a>      <a title="Christine (weereader)" class="user" name="Christine (weereader)" href="/user/show/39719286-christine-weereader">Christine (weereader)</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9781408845646" href="/book/show/24548235-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/39719286-christine-weereader?shelf=read-2015">read-2015</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1410869250" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer7530585011228308967">This my first time rereading this book in four years and it is just as magical and brilliant as I remembered.<br />The artwork by Jim Kay is absolutely beautiful and it's so exciting to see the world we know and love re-imagined! I can't wait to see the rest of the series illustrated. <br />This time reading it I found myself feeling a lot more emotional about Harry and his life. He is so young! I feel so sorry for him and angry that he was left to have an awful upbringing by the magical world. Whereas when</span>  <span id="freeText7530585011228308967" style="display:none">This my first time rereading this book in four years and it is just as magical and brilliant as I remembered.<br />The artwork by Jim Kay is absolutely beautiful and it's so exciting to see the world we know and love re-imagined! I can't wait to see the rest of the series illustrated. <br />This time reading it I found myself feeling a lot more emotional about Harry and his life. He is so young! I feel so sorry for him and angry that he was left to have an awful upbringing by the magical world. Whereas when I read it multiple times as a child I was mainly just excited about the magic.<br />The world building in this book is absolutely phenomenal and it's just amazing the way that JK Rowling manages to create such a believable and detailed magical system that fits in with the world we know. This time reading it I was happy to notice more of the references to the real world that went completely over my head when I was younger.<br />I love reading about the blossoming friendship between Harry, Ron and Hermione and it's so great to read about Harry finally finding a place he can call home.<br />I can't help but see Dumbeldore as being very manipulative from the start, so it's interesting to read about him with a new perspective. I also just can't bring myself to like Snape, nothing excuses someone being so horrible to wee children!<br /><br />This isn't the best review because this book is just perfect and I can hardly even put into world everything I love about this book!<br /></span>  <a data-text-id="7530585011228308967" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div> href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/80584153" />    <a title="Melanie" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie"><img alt="Melanie" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/80584153?book_show_action=false">Aug 20, 2016</a>      <a title="Melanie" class="user" name="Melanie" href="/user/show/3030788-melanie">Melanie</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=witches">witches</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=magic">magic</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/3030788-melanie?shelf=middle-grade">middle-grade</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer80584153" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer4458404964642675402"><i> U+201CIt does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.U+201D </i><br><br>I've sat at my desk for over an hour and I still, after all these years, do not think I can review this book properly. All I can say is that <i>Harry Potter</i> feels like home, and every page of this book feels like magic; and not the magic that has to do with wizards or Hogwarts, but magic that has to do with love that is all encompassing. <br><br>This book was published nearly twenty years ago, but when I opened this book to the first page it felt lik</span>  <span id="freeText4458404964642675402" style="display:none"><i> U+201CIt does not do to dwell on dreams and forget to live.U+201D </i><br><br>I've sat at my desk for over an hour and I still, after all these years, do not think I can review this book properly. All I can say is that <i>Harry Potter</i> feels like home, and every page of this book feels like magic; and not the magic that has to do with wizards or Hogwarts, but magic that has to do with love that is all encompassing. <br><br>This book was published nearly twenty years ago, but when I opened this book to the first page it felt like not a day had passed. I really don't have any amount of words that I can string together to tell you how this book makes me feel. J.K. Rowling will always set the bar for how a series <i>should</i> be written, because <i>Harry Potter</i> is written with love, and it makes all the difference. <b>Always.</b><br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1429509074ra/14597460.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><a href="https://www.twitter.com/meltotheany" rel="nofollow">Twitter</a> | <a href="http://www.twitch.tv/meltotheany/profile" rel="nofollow">Twitch</a></span>  <a data-text-id="4458404964642675402" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> I WILL.<br /><br /><b>My rating system</b>: (I <b>do</b> use half stars.)<br /><b>5</b> - <b>I do not use the 5 star</b>. Not because a book might not be worthy, but because a book is never perfect.<br /><b>4</b> - I <b>loved</b> it! There weren't too many flaws, and I had no trouble getting through it. (A 4 star rating is the highest rating I've ever given a book.)<br /><b>3</b> - I <b>enjoyed</b> the book, but there we're flaws that made me enjoy it less.<br /><b>2</b> - I <b>finished</b> the book, alt="Abigail" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1469056069p2/32620550.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1115415851?book_show_action=false">Jan 05, 2016</a>      <a title="Abigail" class="user" name="Abigail" href="/user/show/32620550-abigail">Abigail</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780545790352" href="/book/show/24490481-harry-potter-and-the-sorcerer-s-stone">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1115415851" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15496886452789301210">First Read: Summer 2009 <br />Last Read: January 2016<br /><br />Five stars, of course!<br />There is no greater home than the Harry Potter books. I adore these books more than I can ever express in words. The first major series I ever read, the books that got me into reading, my favorite series. <br />It was so nice to read this book again and the pictures were an added bonus, Jim Kay is a wonderful artist. J.K. Rowling's words are so great. Being back with Harry, Ron, Hermione, Neville, Fred and George, Hagrid, and everyon</span>  <span id="freeText15496886452789301210" style="display:none">First Read: Summer 2009 <br />Last Read: January 2016<br /><br />Five stars, of course!<br />There is no greater home than the Harry Potter books. I adore these books more than I can ever express in words. The first major series I ever read, the books that got me into reading, my favorite series. <br />It was so nice to read this book again and the pictures were an added bonus, Jim Kay is a wonderful artist. J.K. Rowling's words are so great. Being back with Harry, Ron, Hermione, Neville, Fred and George, Hagrid, and everyone else made me so happy. There are some things that I had forgotten like how much I dislike the Dursley's, the purple and black fire walls scene at the end, and how much I love Dumbledore. So those were great to revisit. <br /><br />If you haven't already, pick up these books. They are so worth it. <br />I'll keep waiting on my Hogwarts letter, even though it almost feels like I've already been.</span>  <a data-text-id="15496886452789301210" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview"  <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer143193399" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17116317484096440011"><b>Update 2</b>: 30th October 2014. <br />Oh my God. Sex for the ears, if anything.<br /><br /><b>Update 1</b>: 13th October 2014. <br />Re-started the series in audio book form. Needless to say, the hour's drive to university has become so much less painful. Coincidentally, as with my first real page experience, this book has now earned the trophy of my first real audio book experience as well. <br />Stephen Fry version highly recommended. <br /><br /><br /><br /><br /><br />My first real read at the tender age of 10. right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/677488321?book_show_action=false">Jul 14, 2016</a>      <a title="Mariah" class="user" name="Mariah" href="/user/show/22371819-mariah">Mariah</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer677488321" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17606148631170401092">My boyfriend and I are read this book together this summer. My goal was to get him to read more since it is one of my favorite hobbies, so I let him pick the book we read. He chose Harry Potter. Well, I guess it was about time I finally read this book :P Not to brag or anythingU+2026 but finished before him ;) haha. I enjoyed this book. It was a really good kids book. It is a fast, easy read, but like I said earlier it was defiantly written for someone younger.<br /><br />I would give this book a 3.5 stars, so I</span>  <span id="freeText17606148631170401092" style="display:none">My boyfriend and I are read this book together this summer. My goal was to get him to read more since it is one of my favorite hobbies, so I let him pick the book we read. He chose Harry Potter. Well, I guess it was about time I finally read this book :P Not to brag or anythingU+2026 but finished before him ;) haha. I enjoyed this book. It was a really good kids book. It is a fast, easy read, but like I said earlier it was defiantly written for someone younger.<br /><br />I would give this book a 3.5 stars, so I am rounding it up to 4 stars!</span>  <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1336880109" />    <a title="JungBook" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/40080783-jungbook"><img alt="JungBook" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1477015645p2/40080783.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1336880109?book_show_action=false">Mar 28, 2016</a>      <a title="JungBook" class="user" name="JungBook" href="/user/show/40080783-jungbook">JungBook</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/40080783-jungbook?shelf=books-i-own">books-i-own</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1336880109" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer1014731924402268865">I loved this book, I loved how there was a mystery that Harry had to solve among being new to Hogwarts school of witchcraft and wizardry. It was beautifully written, and although marked as a "Childrens book", I being a teenager still loved it. When you find out the teacher that was working for Voldemort I gasped so loud my mother received a noise complaint. I read it in the summer and finished it in a matter of days. Overall: 5 stars</span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1336880109">  <td </div>  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_732619942" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/732619942" />    <a title="Deborah Markus" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/954028-deborah-markus"><img alt="Deborah Markus" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442990055p2/954028.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/732619942?book_show_action=false">Aug 06, 2014</a>      <a title="Deborah Markus" class="user" name="Deborah Markus" href="/user/show/954028-deborah-markus">Deborah Markus</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747532699" href="/book/show/848654.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>            </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer732619942" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17859498857687804644">I'm the only person in the world with <i>mixed</i> feelings about the Harry Potter books. Most readers love them. There are non-readers who are indifferent to them as they are to all other books; others who go solely by the fact that they're "children's" books and therefore believe it's ridiculous for adults to read and enjoy them; and of course a legion of similarly anti-literacy folk who have decided the Harry Potter books are immoral. These people, who read and enjoy Tolkien, C.S. Lewis, and stories</span>  <span id="freeText17859498857687804644" style="display:none">I'm the only person in the world with <i>mixed</i> feelings about the Harry Potter books. Most readers love them. There are non-readers who are indifferent to them as they are to all other books; others who go solely by the fact that they're "children's" books and therefore believe it's ridiculous for adults to read and enjoy them; and of course a legion of similarly anti-literacy folk who have decided the Harry Potter books are immoral. These people, who read and enjoy Tolkien, C.S. Lewis, and stories about Merlin and King Arthur, have concluded that the Potter universe is an evil place because it has magic and witches. All righty, then. <br /><br />I suppose there are readers who genuinely dislike the Harry Potter books. I haven't come across them, but they must be out there <i>somewhere.</i> And of course there must be readers who <i>say</i> they dislike them when what they mean is, they're wildly jealous that they didn't write them.<br /><br />I don't belong in any of those categories. I admire the fine writing, characterization, dialogue, and world-building Rowling has done. And exactly because her writing is so good, the one flaw I've found pains me to the point that I can't read these with the pure pleasure they give so many others.<br /><br />The only person I've talked to about this who's been willing to listen long enough to understand what I'm saying is the one person I know who hasn't read the books and has no plans to. He thinks I make a valid point. <i>Everyone else</i> I've attempted to engage on this topic has responded, "You're saying something bad about Harry Potter. You must be bad. I hate you. Please leave my home." Or words to that effect. <br /><br />I'll grant you that accepting flaws in things we love is a little-taught skill in this world. It's almost as rare as seeing good qualities in those we hate. This is as true with books as it is with people, and it's tragic. I have yet to meet someone who can acknowledge the admirable qualities of books they can't stand. I don't mean genuinely bad books, the kind that will be pulped a year after they were printed (if they last that long) or that will never make it to paper in the first place not because technology is awesome but because *nobody* wants to waste the paper on these works. No, I mean books that have stood the test of time but who have as many haters as lovers.<br /><br />Perfect example: <i>Little Women.</i> People adore this book, or they despise it.<br /><br />Listen up: "Little Women" is corny, mawkish, and sentimental. It's also wise, funny, and strong. Whether you like the book or you hate it, if you can't admit that <i>all of this is true</i> and this can all be true <i>at the same time about the same book,</i> you have a serious ego problem. <br /><br />You can't admit that the book you love could have <i>anything</i> wrong with it. ("Krinkle, krinkle, 'ittle 'tar"? Really? That's not cringe-inducing? Calling a grown woman "Marmee" isn't cringe-inducing? Having the one black child at Jo's school for boys be the best singer isn't <i>seriously</i> cringe-inducing?). Or else you refuse to entertain the idea that anything you hate could have anything <i>right</i> about it. (Marmee's advice to Meg about the difference between the flashing tempers of the March girls and the temperament of the man Meg married stands the test of time <i>very</i> well, as do plenty of the other observations of humanity -- when Jo laughingly admits that she's well enough to go on a carriage ride with Laurie, but not well enough to do disagreeable chores, and then karma kicks her in the arse. Which it tends to do a lot in this book.)<br /><br />Put your ego aside when thinking about and discussing literature. Good books are not saints. They should be admired, enjoyed, learned from, and reread; but they should also be critically examined. And if I've done all that with the Harry Potter books <i>and</i> I've found something I think is a serious flaw, it would be nice to be able to <i>discuss</i> that, rather than be glared and yelled at (yes, both have happened, and yes, I'm still angry) because I have the unmitigated gall to find something wrong with Saint Jo.<br /><br />For anyone who's still reading: I'm very uncomfortable with one aspect of the world Rowling has created. Specifically, I don't think her justification for hiding the existence of magic from the world of ordinary humans stands up well in a court of ethics.<br /><br />This is a review of the first book, so I'll only go into what she says here. When Harry Potter first learns who is parents really are, Hagrid is furious at the Dursleys for not having told him anything about what he calls Harry's world. <i>"Our</i> world, I mean. <i>Your</i> world. <i>My</i> world. Yer parents' world." <br /><br />It's terribly wrong not to have told Harry who and what he is, and who and what his parents were. Agreed. <br /><br />How, then, is it all right to hide what is, after all, the <i>real</i> world from the majority of its inhabitants? <br /><br />How is it all right to scorn them for not having magic while at the same time doing everything to keep them from knowing magic exists?<br /><br />Don't say there's no scorn. "Muggle" is hardly a term of endearment. (Yes, I'm jumping ahead of myself and I promised I wouldn't, but "mud-blood" is nothing but an extension of the condescension contained in "Muggle.") And as for the attitude towards the mundane world, look at Hagrid -- one of the good guys, certainly, and a very appealing character:<br /><br />"Although Hagrid seemed to know where he was going, he was obviously not used to getting there in an ordinary way. He got stuck in the ticket barrier on the Underground and complained loudly that the seats were too small and the trains too slow.<br /><br />'I don't know how the Muggles manage without magic,' he said, as they climbed a broken-down escalator."<br /><br />We manage because you won't let us do otherwise. And then you sneer at the job we do.<br /><br />Let me ask you something: Do you really believe that "separate but equal" can be both? That's not how it works in the real world, and it's not how it works in Potter's world. The magical beings there are an elite minority, and they like it that way. They have the power. They're hanging on to it by force (more about that in later books), even when that puts the inhabitants of the mundane world at risk (WAY more about that in later books).<br /><br />Let me ask you something else: If you read and enjoy Austen's novels in the way that many people do -- taking pleasure in imagining yourself a member of that world -- you imagine yourself as one of the genteel, right? Not one of the servants. We see very little of them, and they have miserable lives. The power situation in Austen's time was horribly imbalanced and unfair. Austen wasn't in much of a position to do anything about it; but at least she didn't have her characters brag all the time about how awesome it was to be of the land-owning class, and how pathetic those stupid servants are.<br /><br />In fact, the one character I can think of who <i>does</i> complain about servants is Aunt Norris, and she's an out-and-out villain. Her observations on the serving class are meant to reinforce just what a nasty piece of work she is.<br /><br />One person I know claimed that in the Potter universe, the magic-users keep their existence and powers a secret in order to protect themselves. That's contradicted later -- I think in book #3, in which Harry reads a textbook about how much real witches enjoy being burned at the stake because it tickles and doesn't do them any harm -- but for now I'll just point out what Hagrid says when Harry asks why the Ministry of Magic "keeps it from the Muggles that there's still witches an' wizards up an' down the country."<br /><br />"Blimey, Harry, everyone'd be wantin' magic solutions to their problems. Nah, we're best left alone."<br /><br />If Rowling wanted to make a universe in which a failed attempt had been made in the past to live on equal terms with the non-magic world, and that attempt had led to great suffering and many lives lost on <i>both</i> sides, that would be perfectly tenable. (And fascinating. Somebody, write that book. Okay, I will.) If she wanted to claim that magic-users would be persecuted by the ordinary humans, and the magicians might have the magic but the mundane world had the sheer numbers and a lot of nasty technology on their side, <i>that</i> would certainly work. And then I could read these books without a qualm.<br /><br />Instead, she's created a world in which a ruling class cheerfully admits that they <i>like</i> having all the really cool stuff and they're jolly well not going to share with those foolish mortals who are so stupid, they have to struggle up broken escalators.<br /><br />What troubles me even more than her making this decision (which, as I've pointed out, is <i>not</i> the only way to go if you want to have a world of hidden magic) is how enthusiastically her readers have embraced it. There are "No Muggles Allowed" posters and Facebook pages. Created and enjoyed by people who don't seem to realize that, just as they'd more likely be a servant than gentility in Austen's world, odds are good they'd be Muggles in Rowling's. <br /><br />People who have felt odd and left out all their lives naturally embrace the idea that secretly, they're special and strong -- magical, even. I only question the idea that having wonderful abilities has to go hand in hand with lording it over those who don't. How is the Potter universe's attitude toward non-magic users any different from Malfoy's gloating over his entirely inherited monetary wealth, and sneering at Ron's poverty?<br /><br />I'm very uncomfortable with the Potter universe because I don't have the ego to believe I'd be one of the special ones. I'm rereading these with my son because he doesn't remember them very well and his grandmother kindly lent us an entire hardcover library of the British editions. This journey has its pleasures, but it's the last I'll take to the Potter world. It's no place for Muggles.<br /><br />UPDATE: I'm now about a hundred pages into the British edition of the last Harry Potter book, and I'm already seriously considering rereading the whole series just to have the entire, incredibly complex plot fresh in my head for once. Yes, the things that bug me philosophically about this series still bother me; but the writing is just too good for even cranky old me to resist. </span>  <a data-text-id="17859498857687804644" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="reviewTextContainer1339167088" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer949164751976728510">Amo questo libro, amo questa saga, amo zia Rowling <3 </span>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review1339167088">  <td colspan="2">    <div ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_201711823" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/201711823" />    <a title="Hayat" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/6116230-hayat"><img alt="Hayat" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1420050859p2/6116230.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/201711823?book_show_action=false">Dec 04, 2015</a>      <a title="Hayat" class="user" name="Hayat" href="/user/show/6116230-hayat">Hayat</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span href="/book/show/7955579-harry-potter-and-the-philosopher-s-stone">review of another edition</a>          <div><span class="uitext greyText">Recommends it for: </span>           <span class="uitext reviewText">Everyone</span></div>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6116230-hayat?shelf=family-relationships">family-relationships</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6116230-hayat?shelf=funny-witty-dialog">funny-witty-dialog</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6116230-hayat?shelf=frenemies">frenemies</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6116230-hayat?shelf=adventure">adventure</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/6116230-hayat?shelf=memorable-books">memorable-books</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer201711823" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer10024032622645292111"><b>HP is my number one book series for a reread!</b> <br>Reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling">Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone</a> is like meeting an old friend. It never gets old and I'll never get tired of reading it!<br><br><b>U+201CThere are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.U+201D </b><br><br>You can't help falling in love with reading after discovering the Harry Potter series as a young reader. This is the magical place where book worms are born!!HP turns reluctant reade</span>  <span id="freeText10024032622645292111" style="display:none"><b>HP is my number one book series for a reread!</b> <br>Reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling">Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone</a> is like meeting an old friend. It never gets old and I'll never get tired of reading it!<br><br><b>U+201CThere are some things you can't share without ending up liking each other, and knocking out a twelve-foot mountain troll is one of them.U+201D </b><br><br>You can't help falling in love with reading after discovering the Harry Potter series as a young reader. This is the magical place where book worms are born!!HP turns reluctant readers into series bookworms and devourers of book series, and this is true for my eleven year old daughter. <br><br>I began reading the Harry Potter series to her two years ago and she quickly fell in love with the HP world and characters. She laughed, cried, celebrated with and cheered for HP and his friends. She can even remember the names of each of the characters in the whole series! <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449228485i/17254088._SX540_.png" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Reading Harry Potter has opened up a world of books for her and now she's reading <b>Gail carriger's</b> <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/20980648.Waistcoats___Weaponry__Finishing_School___3_" title="Waistcoats & Weaponry (Finishing School, #3) by Gail Carriger">Waistcoats & Weaponry</a> book three in the <b>Finishing School series</b> and she has already finished reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/337537.The_Naughtiest_Girl_in_the_School__The_Naughtiest_Girl___1_" title="The Naughtiest Girl in the School (The Naughtiest Girl, #1) by Enid Blyton">The Naughtiest Girl in the School</a> series, a few YA (middle grade) paranormal books, <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7938275.The_Hunger_Games_Trilogy_Boxset__The_Hunger_Games___1_3_" title="The Hunger Games Trilogy Boxset (The Hunger Games, #1-3) by Suzanne Collins">The Hunger Games Trilogy Boxset</a> and my YA horror book <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/7619057.Warm_Bodies__Warm_Bodies___1_" title="Warm Bodies (Warm Bodies, #1) by Isaac Marion">Warm Bodies</a>, and she loved it! I think my little bookworm is about to raid my stash of books and I better move my romance/grown up books out of the way until she's a bit older.<br><br><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/hostedimages/1449228485ra/17254089.gif" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>Once again, I finished reading <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling">Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone</a> but this time I read it with my nine year old son. He's a reluctant reader who loves the outdoors and computer games so I decided to use HP to improve his reading skills and perhaps help him discover love of books.<br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449232455i/17254389._SY540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>He loves watching the HP movies (only the first three) but this is the first time he has read <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/27789762.Harry_Potter_and_Philosopher_s_Stone" title="Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone by J.K Rowling">Harry Potter and Philosopher's Stone</a> and he tells me the book is better than the movie! I'm so proud of him! He's upset the movies left out Peeves the Poltergeist, the prankster ghost and his new favourite character. He's already quoting The Philosopher's Stone (and he's adding a few twists of his own) and it's pretty funny and adorable! <br><br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449229702i/17254195._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br>We've already started <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/15881.Harry_Potter_and_the_Chamber_of_Secrets__Harry_Potter___2_" title="Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (Harry Potter, #2) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets</a>, It's going to take us a long time to finish the HP series but it'll all be worth it in the end. <br><br>Already a new generation is discovering the phenomenal, magical and beautiful series that is Harry Potter and I'm so happy to play a small part in this discovery. <br><img src="https://i.gr-assets.com/images/S/compressed.photo.goodreads.com/hostedimages/1449234727i/17254719._SX540_.jpg" class="gr-hostedUserImg"><br><br><b>J.K. Rowling's</b>, humour, incredible, imaginative and easily accessible writing skills makes reading HP is as easy as...<b>U+201CSwish and flick.U+201D</b> <br><br></span>  <a data-text-id="10024032622645292111" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review201711823">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link201711823" likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_201711823" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_201711823" ref="like" class="jsLike  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_139643694" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/139643694" />    <a title="Adam" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1394221-adam"><img alt="Adam" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1269213228p2/1394221.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/139643694?book_show_action=false">Sep 03, 2014</a>      <a title="Adam" class="user" name="Adam" href="/user/show/1394221-adam">Adam</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">did not like it</span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span><span title="did not like it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1394221-adam?shelf=childrens">childrens</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1394221-adam?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer139643694" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer15169979986456650471">Awful in every way. The whole book is centered on lame, even deplorable ideas. First, it divides people into the wizardly and the non-wizardly in a class system. That's a fairly lame idea already, but other than deriding some of the snobby elitists among the wizardly class, it is itself ridiculously elitist, presenting its only non-wizardly people as an overblown, idiotic parody of middle class small-mindedness, conformity, and materialism, and making the elevation into the wizard class an</span>  <span id="freeText15169979986456650471" style="display:none">Awful in every way. The whole book is centered on lame, even deplorable ideas. First, it divides people into the wizardly and the non-wizardly in a class system. That's a fairly lame idea already, but other than deriding some of the snobby elitists among the wizardly class, it is itself ridiculously elitist, presenting its only non-wizardly people as an overblown, idiotic parody of middle class small-mindedness, conformity, and materialism, and making the elevation into the wizard class an unequivocally good thing. Second, it makes the magical into the mundane. Otherworldly and magical things, things beyond the everyday, are trivialized by transposing them into a world of magic shops and wizard schools essentially no different from non-magic shops and non-wizard schools. (It doesn't help that all the magical things are stock s, with absolutely no originality or imagination.)<br /><br />Outside its center of lameness, the book fails in all its basic storytelling s. It's written in a completely standardized kids-book style, full of simplistic exaggerations, stock phrases, and twee comments from the narrator. Even if that style didn't irritate me with its obviousness and simplification, it's utterly indistinct here: the words have no verve. It does nothing of note to create suspense, excitement, pathos, vivid imagery, or anything else. And the dialogue is flat and unnatural, lacking any distinct voices.<br /><br />Similarly, all its characters are clichesU+2014the know-it-all girl, the goofy, good-hearted guy, the classist snob, etc.U+2014that are given no definition or nuance beyond their stereotypes. Actually, they're so vague that they lack even the definiteness of their stereotypes. The villains are given still less: Snape is mean and punishes kids unfairly, Voldemort is evil and kills people, and that's it. And the characters' personality and feelings are related in the most simplistic ways. Harry Potter himself is just a cliched cipher of wish-fulfillment, the mistreated kid with no friends who's really the most special of all kids and destined for greatness.<br /><br />The overarching narrative is still another cliche: a journey away from home, in which kids learn and grow, and a move into an upper-class world full of possibilities and glamor and excitement. Within that, everything is just more lame cliches of school life and childhood friendships. There's also the kids being tested, doing some of that learning and growing, by foiling an evil plot. But the evil plot is painfully contrived (especially the ridiculous bit where all the characters conveniently get to show what they're good atU+2014blech), so undeveloped that it barely registers, and carrying no weight. It also revolves around the ultimate cliche of misdirection: the person you least expect did it! And he's a non-character, defined only by being nervous and stuttering enough to be the person you'd least expect.<br /><br />Finally, Quidditch is the stupidest sport ever.</span>  <a data-text-id="15169979986456650471" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr class="no_border feedFooterReview" id="update_comment_stuff_Review139643694">  <td colspan="2">    <div class="updateActionLinks">        <a class="right flag" rel="nofollow" id="flag_link139643694" title="Flag this review as inappropriate." href="/flaggedew?resource_id=139643694&resource_type=Review&return_url=/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone">flag</a>      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_139643694'><a id="like_count_review_139643694" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/139643694?resource_type=Review"><span class="likesCount">16 likes</span></a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a id="like_action_review_139643694" rel="nofollow" data-like-container-id="like_container_review_139643694" ref="like" class="jsLike like_it gr-button gr-button--small loadingLink" data-remote="true" data-method="post" href="/rating?count_on_right=false&format=json&lc=16&rating[page]=10&rating[rating]=1&rating[resource_id]=139643694&rating[resource_type]=Review">Like</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></span>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a id="commentLink_139643694" href="#" onclick="comment_form_for(&#39;review&#39;, 139643694, true, &#39;&#39;); return false;">10 comments</a>U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0<a href="/review/show/139643694?book_show_action=false&from_review_page=10">see review</a>    </div>    <div id='comments_for_review_139643694' style='display: none;'><div class='brown_comment'><span class="loadingLinkSpan"><a class="loadingLink" data-remote="true" href="/review/139643694/comments?reverse=true">View all 10 comments</a><span class="loadingAnimation"></span><span class="loadingError"></span></span></div><div id="comment_144859024" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="Adam" href="/user/show/1394221-adam"><img src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1269213228p1/1394221.jpg" alt="1394221" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/1394221-adam">Adam</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer2512568237985526160"><i>Alana wrote: "I mean not to be rude, but do you think this book may have sounded like it was meant for kids because it was meant for kids"</i><br />I'm not sure</span>  <span id="freeText2512568237985526160" style="display:none"><i>Alana wrote: "I mean not to be rude, but do you think this book may have sounded like it was meant for kids because it was meant for kids"</i><br />I'm not sure which part of my review you're referring to. The bit about the prose style? I like a lot of children's literature, so it's not like I'm fundamentally predisposed to dislike anything meant for kids.</span>  <a data-text-id="2512568237985526160" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span class="xhrCommentFooter greyText">      Dec 26, 2015 10:57AM    </span>  </div>  <div class="clear"></div></div><div id="comment_153433741" class="brown_comment">  <div class="xhr_comment_photo">    t<a alt="The Maivy" href="/user/show/57133867-the-maivy"><img src="https://s.gr-assets.com/assetsophoto/user/u_25x33-ccd24e68f4773d33a41ce08c3a34892e.png" alt="U 25x33" /></a>  </div>  <div class="xhr_comment_body">    <a style="font-weight:bold" href="/user/show/57133867-the-maivy">The Maivy</a>      <span id="freeTextContainer6604671321289721634">This book was meant to draw in younger children. Read the rest of the series and you'll see why Harry Potter is a masterpiece. The character and</span>  <span id="freeText6604671321289721634" style="display:none">This book was meant to draw in younger children. Read the rest of the series and you'll see why Harry Potter is a masterpiece. The character and writing development is AWESOME.</span>  <a data-text-id="6604671321289721634" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>    <br/>    <span      <span class='likeItContainer' id='like_container_review_1759926364'><a id="like_count_review_1759926364" rel="nofollow" href="/rating/voters/1759926364?resource_type=Review"><span ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_690902253" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/690902253" />    <a title="Cristina" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/22978411-cristina"><img alt="Cristina" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1465333252p2/22978411.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/690902253?book_show_action=false">Jun 17, 2016</a>      <a title="Cristina" class="user" name="Cristina" href="/user/show/22978411-cristina">Cristina</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9788478886548" href="/book/show/15868.Harry_Potter_y_la_piedra_filosofal">review of another edition</a>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=20th-century">20th-century</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/22978411-cristina?shelf=wwc-uk">wwc-uk</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer690902253" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer17966107228630293335">Aviso antes de empezar que esta no es una reseU+00F1a especial ni el relato de cU+00F3mo comenzU+00F3 mi amor por la literatura. SU+00F3lo es la historia de alguien que, como tantos otros de mi generaciU+00F3n, tuvo la maravillosa fortuna de crecer junto a Harry. <br /><br />No estoy segura de si Harry llegU+00F3 a mi vida el dU+00EDa que cumplU+00ED nueve o diez aU+00F1os. Unos amigos de mis abuelos, a sabiendas de cuU+00E1nto me gustaba leer, me regalaron por mi cumpleaU+00F1os mi mU+00E1s que manoseado ejemplar de Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal, diciendo que</span>  <span id="freeText17966107228630293335" style="display:none">Aviso antes de empezar que esta no es una reseU+00F1a especial ni el relato de cU+00F3mo comenzU+00F3 mi amor por la literatura. SU+00F3lo es la historia de alguien que, como tantos otros de mi generaciU+00F3n, tuvo la maravillosa fortuna de crecer junto a Harry. <br /><br />No estoy segura de si Harry llegU+00F3 a mi vida el dU+00EDa que cumplU+00ED nueve o diez aU+00F1os. Unos amigos de mis abuelos, a sabiendas de cuU+00E1nto me gustaba leer, me regalaron por mi cumpleaU+00F1os mi mU+00E1s que manoseado ejemplar de Harry Potter y la piedra filosofal, diciendo que el libro se habU+00EDa puesto de moda y que parecU+00EDa que gustaba bastante. La verdad sea dicha, mi capacidad crU+00EDtica era nula en esos momentos y leU+00EDa todo lo que caU+00EDa en mis manos, asU+00ED que no le di la menor importancia. Hasta que comencU+00E9 a leer y Harry me atrapU+00F3.<br /><br />No soy consciente de cU+00F3mo llegaron a mis manos ni el segundo ni el tercer libro, pero sU+00E9 que devorU+00E9 uno detrU+00E1s de otro y que sufrU+00ED una tremenda decepciU+00F3n cuando me acerquU+00E9 a la papelerU+00EDa de al lado de mi casa y me dijeron que el cuarto libro no estaba publicado. U+00A1Fue la primera vez que tuve que esperar a que se publicase un libro!<br /><br />EsperU+00E9 mi carta de Hogwarts con ahU+00EDnco durante un par de aU+00F1os. SoU+00F1aba con llegar allU+00ED y vivir las aventuras que vivU+00EDa Harry. Tengo el recuerdo de estar en mi habitaciU+00F3n haciendo cU+00E1balas sobre mi edad y la de los personajes para saber si coincidirU+00EDa o no con ellos en clase. <s>SU+00ED, siempre he sido un poco fantasiosa.</s> <br /><br />Harry Potter me descubriU+00F3 un mundo repleto de magia, amistad y fantasU+00EDa. A dU+00EDa de hoy, mis ejemplares de la saga siguen teniendo un lugar privilegiado en mis estanterU+00EDas, a pesar de tener los lomos desgastados y las pU+00E1ginas amarillentas de tanto leerlos. Soy consciente de que no son libros perfectos y de que la saga tiene contradicciones y errores, pero nada me ha hecho llorar como la muerte de Fred o la de Dobby. Y ningU+00FAn otro libro me impulsU+00F3 a escribir, tanto como lo hizo este.<br /><br />Gracias a Harry, me adentrU+00E9 en el mundo del fanfiction donde, no sU+00F3lo mejore muchU+00EDsimo como escritora y me animU+00E9 a publicar (de manera amateur), sino que conocU+00ED a personas maravillosas que forman parte de mi vida desde hace aU+00F1os, enriqueciU+00E9ndola de muchU+00EDsimas formas. <br /><br />La saga de Harry Potter me sigue haciendo soU+00F1ar tanto hoy como la primera vez que me adentrU+00E9 en la normalidad del nU+00FAmero 4 de Privet Drive. Brindemos para que U+00ABEl niU+00F1o que viviU+00F3 U+00BB siga viviendo mucho tiempo.<br /><br />Gracias por todos estos aU+00F1os, J.K.<br /><br />Una orgullosa Huffie.</span>  <a data-text-id="17966107228630293335" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext buttons">          <tr  </div>    <div class="ListBrownSeparator"></div>  <div class="friendReviews ListBrown" >    <div class="section">      <div id="review_1115256584" class="review" itemprop="reviews" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/1115256584" />    <a title="Evey" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/19222970-evey"><img alt="Evey" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1417196082p2/19222970.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/1115256584?book_show_action=false">Mar 19, 2015</a>      <a title="Evey" class="user" name="Evey" href="/user/show/19222970-evey">Evey</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">it was amazing</span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="it was amazing" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span></span>                  <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=favorites">favorites</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=female-kickass-heroins">female-kickass-heroins</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=young-adult">young-adult</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=series">series</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=magicians">magicians</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=2014-reading-challenge">2014-reading-challenge</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=2014-tbr-challenge">2014-tbr-challenge</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/19222970-evey?shelf=2014-paranormal-fantasy-challenge">2014-paranormal-fantasy-challenge</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer1115256584" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer11501826006914105822"><b>5 magic stars</b><br /><br />Reading this made me happy. It was like going back to my childhood, when I first heard (and read) about Harry Potter. I was/am one of the lucky ones from the "Potter generation", and I have nothing but good things to say about the story, the world, the characters that J. K. Rowling created.<br /><br />This is exactly the type of book children and young teens should read. Nowadays, mainly girls, are reading stuff that are marketed for older and more mature readers, focused on topics they know no</span>  <span id="freeText11501826006914105822" style="display:none"><b>5 magic stars</b><br /><br />Reading this made me happy. It was like going back to my childhood, when I first heard (and read) about Harry Potter. I was/am one of the lucky ones from the "Potter generation", and I have nothing but good things to say about the story, the world, the characters that J. K. Rowling created.<br /><br />This is exactly the type of book children and young teens should read. Nowadays, mainly girls, are reading stuff that are marketed for older and more mature readers, focused on topics they know nothing about yet and probably shouldn't read about due to not being ready to get the grasp of it and a whole, objective vision of their own after reading said stories (for example, "BDSM" stuff that in reality is not BDSM but a "how-to-be-abused-by-a-bastard" guide... You know which book I'm talking about. And that one is not the only book with abuse being glamorized.) <br /><br />This book, even though it's not the <i>very best</i> written book ever, focuses on the value of friendship, family and team work. It portrays flawed, yet strong characters. And not only male characters, but also female, which is currently hard to find nowadays. Women, girls, are normally being depicted as weak and needy, whose only purpose is to <s>serve</s> <i>love</i> a man in order to find their lives complete, and whose happiness depends solely and exclusively in said man. And to get him, in many books friendship is torn apart just for the sake of getting their love interest. In my opinion, we're sending the wrong message to young girls. Many do believe that, indeed, they need a boyfriend to be happy. That if they don't have one, their worth is less or there's something wrong with them. Society itself promotes the message that if you're a woman and you don't get a man, you failed at life. All I can ask myself is <i>why</i>.<br /><br />In the other hand, Harry Potter shows brave characters, all in its own particular way. Characters that through each book continue to grow and develop. That's why I recommend anyone, young or not, to read these books. At least for the happy old times!<br /><br />PS: Proud Ravenclaw here! :D</span>  <a data-text-id="11501826006914105822" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a> itemtype="http://schema.org/Review">  <link itemprop="url" href="https://www.goodreads.com/review/show/19022754" />    <a title="Brad" class="left imgcol" href="/user/show/1022982-brad"><img alt="Brad" src="https://images.gr-assets.com/users/1442484575p2/1022982.jpg" /></a>  <div class="left bodycol">    <div class="reviewHeader uitext stacked">        <a class="reviewDate createdAt right" itemprop="publishDate" href="/review/show/19022754?book_show_action=false">Aug 31, 2009</a>      <a title="Brad" class="user" name="Brad" href="/user/show/1022982-brad">Brad</a>        rated it        <span class=" staticStars"><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10">really liked it</span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p10"></span><span title="really liked it" size="15x15" class="staticStar p0"></span></span>          <span class="greyText">U+00A0 U+00B7 U+00A0</span>          <a class="lightGreyText" title="Hardcover 9780747532699" href="/book/show/848654.Harry_Potter_and_the_Philosopher_s_Stone">review of another edition</a>          <div>    <span class="greyText">Recommended to Brad by: </span>      Michelle Svenson  </div>          <div class="uitext greyText bookshelves">            Shelves:              <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=fantasy">fantasy</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=youth">youth</a>,               <a class="actionLinkLite" href="/review/list/1022982-brad?shelf=read-to-bronte">read-to-bronte</a>          </div>    </div>        <div class="reviewText stacked">              <span id="reviewTextContainer19022754" class="readable"              >            <span id="freeTextContainer9988306040948695037">Is there any point in saying anything about <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a> anymore? Not really. Not as far as critiques go. <br /><br />If I were to delve into some interesting critical analysis of an issue raised in <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">The Philosopher's Stone</a>, or take a critical look at Rowling's authorship, then maybe...but most everything that can be said about liking or disliking the book, about its excellence or its shabbiness has been said.<br /><br />And while I feel I may eventually take a stand for those who appreciate</span>  <span id="freeText9988306040948695037" style="display:none">Is there any point in saying anything about <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter and the Philosopher's Stone</a> anymore? Not really. Not as far as critiques go. <br /><br />If I were to delve into some interesting critical analysis of an issue raised in <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">The Philosopher's Stone</a>, or take a critical look at Rowling's authorship, then maybe...but most everything that can be said about liking or disliking the book, about its excellence or its shabbiness has been said.<br /><br />And while I feel I may eventually take a stand for those who appreciate <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/1077326.J_K__Rowling" title="J.K. Rowling">JK Rowling</a>'s world of witches and wizards, who think that these books occasionally achieve real excellence, who connect emotionally to any one of the impressive characters she has drawn, I officially concede my inability to do so here.<br /><br />But I will make this observation: those who equate the Twilight series to the Harry Potter series for entertainment value, quality of storytelling, cultural influence, influence on literacy, or the writing chops of their authors are people you do NOT want to be taking book advice from.<br /><br />There is more than something in the <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/3.Harry_Potter_and_the_Sorcerer_s_Stone__Harry_Potter___1_" title="Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (Harry Potter, #1) by J.K. Rowling">Harry Potter</a> series worth reading. I couldn't find anything worth reading in the works of <a href="https://www.goodreads.com/author/show/941441.Stephenie_Meyer" title="Stephenie Meyer">Stephenie Meyer</a> (except that it had been published).</span>  <a data-text-id="9988306040948695037" href="#" onclick="swapContent($(this));; return false;">...more</a>          </span>        </div>      <div class="reviewFooter uitext
